hpo_input.name: Elbow flexion contracture
hpo_input.definition: "An elbow contracture that limits the ability of the elbow joint to be extended (straightened), meaning that the elbow is fixed in an flexed (bent) position." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Fixed flexion at the elbow joint

hpo_input.name: Hip contracture
hpo_input.definition: "Lack of full passive range of motion (restrictions in flexion, extension, or other movements) of the hip joint resulting from structural changes of non-bony tissues, such as muscles, tendons, ligaments, joint capsules and/or skin." [PMID:16214063, PMID:24975760, PMID:31282072]

hpo_input.name: obsolete Toe walking
hpo_input.definition: "Toe walking is a pattern of walking in which a person walks on balls of his or her feet, with no contact between the heels and ground. Toe-walking is common in children who are learning to walk, but most children outgrow it around the age of two years. This term refers to the persistence of toe-walking beyond the usual age." [PMID:26709689]

hpo_input.name: Wrist flexion contracture
hpo_input.definition: "A chronic loss of wrist joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevent normal movement of the joints of the wrist." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Flexion contracture
hpo_input.definition: "A flexion contracture is a bent (flexed) joint that cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement of joints." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Flexed joint that cannot be straightened

hpo_input.name: Flexion contracture of toe
hpo_input.definition: "One or more bent (flexed) toe joints that cannot be straightened actively or passively." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

search_results:
Here is a detailed analysis of the six HPO terms related to contractures and toe walking, addressing the three questions for each term:

| HPO Term (ID & Name)                     | More Common & Less Informative for Specific Disease                                    | Rare & Informative for Specific Disease                                               | Specific Gender or Age Group More Likely Affected                                  |
|-----------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **HP:0002987 Elbow flexion contracture** | Common complication after trauma, surgery, fractures, dislocations, burns; often posttraumatic or post-surgical stiffness[1][2][3][4]. Less specific as it can occur in many conditions. | Rare causes include inflammatory diseases (rheumatoid arthritis), heterotopic ossification, or genetic syndromes affecting connective tissue[4]. | More common in adults after trauma or surgery; no specific gender predilection noted[1][2][3]. |
| **HP:0003273 Hip contracture**           | Common in patients with prolonged immobilization, neurological disorders, or after hip surgery; often seen in elderly or those with musculoskeletal diseases[5]. | Rare in congenital or genetic connective tissue disorders causing joint contractures specifically at the hip[5]. | More frequent in elderly or patients with neurological impairment; no clear gender bias[5]. |
| **HP:0040083 obsolete Toe walking**      | Toe walking is common in toddlers learning to walk but persistence beyond age 2 is less common and can be nonspecific[PMID:26709689]. | Persistent toe walking beyond age 2 can be informative for neuromuscular disorders (e.g., cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophies) or autism spectrum disorders[PMID:26709689]. | Mostly observed in young children; no specific gender bias but some neurodevelopmental disorders with toe walking have male predominance. |
| **HP:0001239 Wrist flexion contracture** | Common in patients with trauma, burns, or immobilization of the wrist; often seen in post-injury or post-surgical contexts[5]. | Rare in genetic syndromes or specific neuromuscular diseases causing isolated wrist contractures[5]. | More common in adults with trauma history; no specific gender or age group otherwise. |
| **HP:0001371 Flexion contracture**       | Very broad and common term encompassing contractures at many joints; often seen in immobilization, trauma, arthritis, or neurological conditions[5]. | When isolated or in unusual joints, can be informative for rare connective tissue or neuromuscular disorders[5]. | Occurs across all ages depending on underlying cause; no gender specificity. |
| **HP:0005830 Flexion contracture of toe** | Common in patients with diabetes, neuropathy, or after trauma; often related to chronic mechanical stress or deformity[5]. | Rare in congenital or genetic syndromes causing toe contractures specifically[5]. | More common in adults with chronic conditions; no specific gender bias. |

### Summary of Key Points:

1. **More Common & Less Informative Terms:**
   - *Flexion contracture (HP:0001371)* is very broad and common, thus less specific.
   - *Elbow flexion contracture (HP:0002987)* and *wrist flexion contracture (HP:0001239)* are common post-traumatic or post-surgical complications.
   - *Hip contracture (HP:0003273)* and *flexion contracture of toe (HP:0005830)* are often secondary to immobilization or chronic conditions.
   - *Toe walking (HP:0040083)* is common in toddlers but persistence beyond age 2 is less common.

2. **Rare & Informative Terms:**
   - Persistent *toe walking* beyond age 2 is informative for neuromuscular or neurodevelopmental disorders.
   - Contractures isolated to specific joints without trauma history may indicate rare genetic or connective tissue disorders.
   - Inflammatory or systemic diseases causing contractures (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis causing elbow contracture) are less common but informative.

3. **Age and Gender Associations:**
   - *Toe walking* is primarily a pediatric concern.
   - Contractures due to trauma or surgery (elbow, wrist, hip) are more common in adults.
   - No strong gender predilection is noted for these contractures.
   - Elderly or neurologically impaired patients are more prone to hip contractures.

This analysis integrates clinical context from orthopedic and rehabilitation sources, emphasizing that many contractures are common sequelae of trauma or immobilization, thus less specific, while persistence or occurrence in unusual contexts or age groups may be diagnostically informative.

hpo_input.name: Abnormal pattern of respiration

hpo_input.name: Dimple chin

It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement of joints." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Flexed joint that cannot be straightened

search_results:
Here is a detailed analysis of the provided Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) terms regarding their commonality, informativeness for specific diseases, and any gender or age predilections:

---

### 1. Common and Less Informative HPO Terms for Specific Diseases

These terms are relatively **common** in clinical presentations and often seen across multiple conditions, making them **less specific** or less informative for pinpointing a particular disease:

- **Abnormality of the respiratory system (HP:0002086)**: A broad term encompassing many respiratory issues, common in various diseases.
- **Seizure (HP:0001250)**: Common neurological symptom seen in many disorders.
- **Motor delay (HP:0001270)**: A frequent developmental concern in many pediatric conditions.
- **Scoliosis (HP:0002650)**: Common spinal deformity seen in multiple syndromes and idiopathic cases.
- **Full cheeks (HP:0000293)**: A nonspecific facial feature seen in various syndromes and normal variants.

### 2. Rare and Informative HPO Terms for Specific Diseases

- **Talipes equinovarus (HP:0001762)** (clubfoot): A congenital foot deformity that can be syndromic or isolated.

### 3. Gender or Age Group Predilections

Most of these HPO terms do **not have a strict gender predilection** but may be more common or relevant in certain **age groups**:

### Additional Context on Elbow Flexion Contracture (HP:0002987)

Elbow flexion contracture is a common orthopedic condition that limits elbow extension, often due to trauma, surgery, or inflammation. It is treated initially with conservative methods such as physical therapy, splinting, anti-inflammatory medications, and sometimes corticosteroid injections. Surgical options like capsular release (open or arthroscopic) are considered when conservative treatment fails. Early diagnosis and treatment are important to restore function and prevent worsening stiffness[1][2][4][6][7].

diseases: Congenital Contractures of the Limbs and Face, Hypotonia, and Developmental Delay

hpo_input.name: Delayed speech and language development
hpo_input.definition: "A degree of language development that is significantly below the norm for a child of a specified age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Wide nasal bridge
hpo_input.definition: "Increased breadth of the nasal bridge (and with it, the nasal root)." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:19152422]
synonym: Increased breadth of bridge of nose
Increased width of bridge of nose

hpo_input.name: Enlarged naris
hpo_input.definition: "Increased aperture of the nostril." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Seizure
hpo_input.definition: "A seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterized by a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:15816939]

hpo_input.name: Short columella
hpo_input.definition: "Reduced distance from the anterior border of the naris to the subnasale." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Seizure
hpo_input.definition: "A seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterized by a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:15816939]

hpo_input.name: Long philtrum
hpo_input.definition: "Distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Micrognathia
hpo_input.definition: "Developmental hypoplasia of the mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Pursed lips
hpo_input.definition: "An abnormality of the appearance of the face caused by constant contraction of the lips leading to a puckered or pursed appearance." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Dimple chin
hpo_input.definition: "A persistent midline depression of the skin over the fat pad of the chin." [PMID:19125436]

hpo_input.name: Cerebral atrophy
hpo_input.definition: "Atrophy (wasting, decrease in size of cells or tissue) affecting the cerebrum." [https://orcid.org/0009-0006-4530-3154]

hpo_input.name: Full cheeks
hpo_input.definition: "Increased prominence or roundness of soft tissues between zygomata and mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2972-5481]

hpo_input.name: Hypotonia
hpo_input.definition: "Hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone (the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle). Even when relaxed, muscles have a continuous and passive partial contraction which provides some resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia thus manifests as diminished resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia is not the same as muscle weakness, although the two conditions can co-exist." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:21418198]

hpo_input.name: Camptodactyly
hpo_input.definition: "The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fingers or toes cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Permanent flexion of the finger or toe

hpo_input.name: Adducted thumb
hpo_input.definition: "In the resting position, the tip of the thumb is on, or near, the palm, close to the base of the fourth or fifth finger." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6670-9157, PMID:16235349, PMID:19125433]

hpo_input.name: Global developmental delay
hpo_input.definition: "A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6410-0882, https://orcid.org/0009-0006-4530-3154]

hpo_input.name: Talipes equinovarus
hpo_input.definition: "Talipes equinovarus (also called clubfoot) typically has four main components: inversion and adduction of the forefoot; inversion of the heel and hindfoot; equinus (limitation of extension) of the ankle and subtalar joint; and internal rotation of the leg." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:32491773]

hpo_input.name: Abnormal pattern of respiration
hpo_input.definition: "An anomaly of the rhythm or depth of breathing." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Calcaneovalgus deformity
hpo_input.definition: "This is a postural deformity in which the foot is positioned up against the tibia. The heel (calcaneus) is positioned downward (that is, the ankle is flexed upward), and the heel is turned outward (valgus)." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Foot and ankle bend up toward shin of leg

hpo_input.name: Gastroesophageal reflux
hpo_input.definition: "A condition in which the stomach contents leak backwards from the stomach into the esophagus through the lower esophageal sphincter." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Hip contracture
hpo_input.definition: "Lack of full passive range of motion (restrictions in flexion, extension, or other movements) of the hip joint resulting from structural changes of non-bony tissues, such as muscles, tendons, ligaments, joint capsules and/or skin." [PMID:16214063, PMID:24975760, PMID:31282072]

hpo_input.name: Constipation
hpo_input.definition: "Infrequent or difficult evacuation of feces." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Elbow flexion contracture
hpo_input.definition: "An elbow contracture that limits the ability of the elbow joint to be extended (straightened), meaning that the elbow is fixed in an flexed (bent) position." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Fixed flexion at the elbow joint

hpo_input.name: Inguinal hernia
hpo_input.definition: "Protrusion of the contents of the abdominal cavity through the inguinal canal." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Scoliosis
hpo_input.definition: "The presence of an abnormal lateral curvature of the spine." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Cobb angle greater than ten degrees

hpo_input.name: Central apnea
hpo_input.definition: "Apnea resulting from depression of the respiratory centers in the medulla oblongata. There is a lack of respiratory effort rather than obstruction of airflow." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Esotropia
hpo_input.definition: "A form of strabismus with one or both eyes turned inward ('crossed') to a relatively severe degree, usually defined as 10 diopters or more." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Motor delay
hpo_input.definition: "A type of Developmental delay characterized by a delay in acquiring motor skills." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Delay in development of motor milestones

hpo_input.name: Strabismus
hpo_input.definition: "A misalignment of the eyes so that the visual axes deviate from bifoveal fixation. The classification of strabismus may be based on a number of features including the relative position of the eyes, whether the deviation is latent or manifest, intermittent or constant, concomitant or otherwise and according to the age of onset and the relevance of any associated refractive error." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0986-4123, PMID:26319345]

hpo_input.name: Short neck
hpo_input.definition: "Diminished length of the neck." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Nephrolithiasis
hpo_input.definition: "The presence of calculi (stones) in the kidneys." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

Answer the following three questions for each hpo term:
1. Which of these hpo terms are more common and less informative for a specific disease?
2. Which of these hpo terms are rare and informative for a specific disease?
3. Is there a spesific gender or age group that is more likely to have these hpo terms?
search_results:
# Analysis of HPO Terms for Clinical Significance

Based on the search results provided and clinical knowledge, I'll analyze the HPO terms you've listed across three dimensions:

## Common vs. Rare and Informative Terms

**More Common and Less Informative Terms:**

The following HPO terms appear frequently across many different conditions and therefore have lower diagnostic specificity:

- **Delayed speech and language development (HP:0000750)** - This is one of the most common developmental findings and can result from numerous underlying causes including hearing loss, intellectual disability, autism spectrum disorder, cerebral palsy, and environmental factors[1][4][5]. While clinically important, it is non-specific without additional context.

- **Global developmental delay (HP:0001263)** - This represents a broad category of developmental delays affecting multiple domains and is associated with many different genetic and environmental etiologies[1][3][6].

- **Motor delay (HP:0001270)** - A common finding in many developmental and neurological conditions, making it less specific for diagnosis.

- **Hypotonia (HP:0001252)** - Frequently observed in various neuromuscular and genetic disorders.

- **Constipation (HP:0002019)** and **Gastroesophageal reflux (HP:0002020)** - These are common functional issues that occur across many conditions and populations.

**Rare and Informative Terms:**

The following HPO terms are more specific and informative for particular disease categories:

- **Adducted thumb (HP:0001181)** - This is a relatively specific finding, particularly associated with certain genetic syndromes and neurological conditions affecting motor control.

- **Talipes equinovarus/Clubfoot (HP:0001762)** - A specific structural abnormality often associated with particular genetic syndromes or intrauterine constraints.

- **Micrognathia (HP:0000347)** - A distinctive facial feature associated with specific syndromes such as Pierre Robin sequence and certain genetic conditions.

- **Dimple chin (HP:0010751)** - A relatively specific facial feature that can be associated with particular genetic syndromes.

- **Short columella (HP:0002000)** and **Long philtrum (HP:0000343)** - These specific facial measurements are more informative when present in combination with other features.

- **Central apnea (HP:0002871)** - A specific respiratory finding that suggests involvement of brainstem or central nervous system control mechanisms.

- **Seizure (HP:0001250)** - While not rare, seizures in combination with other features can be highly informative for specific neurological conditions.

## Gender and Age-Related Patterns

**Gender Differences:**

The search results indicate specific gender patterns for certain conditions:

- **Delayed speech and language development** shows a **male predominance**[4]. Maturation delay (developmental language delay) is noted to be more common in boys, with a family history of "late bloomers" often present[4].

- **Motor delay and developmental delays** in general also show a slight male predominance as a risk factor[3].

**Age-Related Patterns:**

- **Delayed speech and language development** is most relevant and detectable in **early childhood**, particularly between ages 12-36 months[6]. Red flags include no babbling by 9 months, no pointing by 12 months, no intelligible words by 16 months, and no two-word phrases by 24 months[6].

- **Global developmental delay** is specifically defined as occurring in **children younger than five years of age**[1][3].

- **Motor delay** is typically assessed in **infants and toddlers** during the first few years of life.

- **Seizures** can occur at any age but may have different etiologies depending on age of onset. Early-onset seizures (in infancy) may suggest different underlying conditions than later-onset seizures.

- **Structural findings** like micrognathia, clubfoot, and columella abnormalities are typically present from **birth or early infancy** and may be detected prenatally or at birth.

- **Respiratory issues** (central apnea, breathing dysregulation) may be more apparent in **neonates and young infants**.

The combination of multiple HPO terms, particularly when rare and specific features cluster together, provides much greater diagnostic value than any single common term like speech delay or developmental delay alone[1][3][6].

hpo_input.name: Elbow flexion contracture
hpo_input.definition: "An elbow contracture that limits the ability of the elbow joint to be extended (straightened), meaning that the elbow is fixed in an flexed (bent) position." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Fixed flexion at the elbow joint

hpo_input.name: Micrognathia
hpo_input.definition: "Developmental hypoplasia of the mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Adducted thumb
hpo_input.definition: "In the resting position, the tip of the thumb is on, or near, the palm, close to the base of the fourth or fifth finger." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6670-9157, PMID:16235349, PMID:19125433]

hpo_input.name: Short columella
hpo_input.definition: "Reduced distance from the anterior border of the naris to the subnasale." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Pursed lips
hpo_input.definition: "An abnormality of the appearance of the face caused by constant contraction of the lips leading to a puckered or pursed appearance." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Wide nasal bridge
hpo_input.definition: "Increased breadth of the nasal bridge (and with it, the nasal root)." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:19152422]
synonym: Increased breadth of bridge of nose
Increased width of bridge of nose

hpo_input.name: Inguinal hernia
hpo_input.definition: "Protrusion of the contents of the abdominal cavity through the inguinal canal." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Dimple chin
hpo_input.definition: "A persistent midline depression of the skin over the fat pad of the chin." [PMID:19125436]

hpo_input.name: Camptodactyly
hpo_input.definition: "The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fingers or toes cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Permanent flexion of the finger or toe

hpo_input.name: Motor delay
hpo_input.definition: "A type of Developmental delay characterized by a delay in acquiring motor skills." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Delay in development of motor milestones

hpo_input.name: Abnormal scapula morphology
hpo_input.definition: "Any abnormality of the scapula, also known as the shoulder blade." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Knee flexion contracture
hpo_input.definition: "A type of knee joint contracture in which the knee is in a fixed bent (flexed) configuration such that it cannot be straightened actively or passively." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:31282072]

hpo_input.name: Short neck
hpo_input.definition: "Diminished length of the neck." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Long philtrum
hpo_input.definition: "Distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Full cheeks
hpo_input.definition: "Increased prominence or roundness of soft tissues between zygomata and mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2972-5481]

hpo_input.name: Enlarged naris
hpo_input.definition: "Increased aperture of the nostril." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Hip contracture
hpo_input.definition: "Lack of full passive range of motion (restrictions in flexion, extension, or other movements) of the hip joint resulting from structural changes of non-bony tissues, such as muscles, tendons, ligaments, joint capsules and/or skin." [PMID:16214063, PMID:24975760, PMID:31282072]

hpo_input.name: Abnormal pattern of respiration
hpo_input.definition: "An anomaly of the rhythm or depth of breathing." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Hypotonia
hpo_input.definition: "Hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone (the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle). Even when relaxed, muscles have a continuous and passive partial contraction which provides some resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia thus manifests as diminished resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia is not the same as muscle weakness, although the two conditions can co-exist." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:21418198]

hpo_input.name: Talipes equinovarus
hpo_input.definition: "Talipes equinovarus (also called clubfoot) typically has four main components: inversion and adduction of the forefoot; inversion of the heel and hindfoot; equinus (limitation of extension) of the ankle and subtalar joint; and internal rotation of the leg." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:32491773]

Answer the following three questions for each hpo term:
1. Which of these hpo terms are more common and less informative for a specific disease?
2. Which of these hpo terms are rare and informative for a specific disease?
3. Is there a spesific gender or age group that is more likely to have these hpo terms?
search_results:
Here is an analysis of the listed HPO terms regarding their commonality, informativeness for specific diseases, and any known gender or age predilections based on the definitions and available clinical context:

---

### 1. **Elbow flexion contracture (HP:0002987)**
- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  This is a relatively common symptom, especially as a complication after elbow trauma, surgery, burns, arthritis, or immobilization. It is considered a *less informative* and more *nonspecific* finding because it can result from many different conditions affecting the elbow joint or surrounding soft tissues[1][2][3][4][5][6][7].  
- **Rare & Informative:**  
  Rarely, if elbow flexion contracture occurs congenitally or in unusual syndromic contexts, it may be more informative. However, generally, it is a secondary symptom rather than a primary diagnostic clue.  
- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  No specific gender predilection. It can occur in all age groups but is more frequent in adults after trauma or surgery. Children may have slightly greater normal elbow flexion range[1].  

---

### 2. **Micrognathia (HP:0000347)**
- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Micrognathia (underdeveloped lower jaw) is a *relatively rare* but *highly informative* feature in genetic syndromes (e.g., Pierre Robin sequence, Treacher Collins syndrome) and congenital disorders. It is a key diagnostic sign in many craniofacial syndromes.  
- **Rare & Informative:**  
  Yes, micrognathia is often considered an informative finding for specific syndromes and developmental disorders.  
- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Typically identified in neonates and infants during developmental assessment. No specific gender bias reported.  

---

### 3. **Adducted thumb (HP:0001181)**
- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Adducted thumb is *uncommon* and considered *informative* for certain genetic syndromes such as Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome and others involving limb anomalies. It is not a common isolated finding.  
- **Rare & Informative:**  
  Yes, it is a useful diagnostic feature in syndromic contexts.  
- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Usually identified in infancy or early childhood. No clear gender predilection.  

---

### 4. **Short columella (HP:0002000)**
- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Short columella is a *relatively uncommon* facial feature and can be *informative* in syndromes affecting nasal and midface development (e.g., some craniofacial dysostoses).  
- **Rare & Informative:**  
  Yes, it can be an informative dysmorphic feature.  
- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Observed from birth or early childhood; no specific gender bias.  

---

### 5. **Pursed lips (HP:0000205)**
- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Pursed lips are a *common* nonspecific facial feature that can appear in various neuromuscular or developmental conditions. It is generally *less informative* alone.  
- **Rare & Informative:**  
  Rarely informative unless part of a syndrome with characteristic facial features.  
- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  No specific gender or age predilection.  

---

### 6. **Wide nasal bridge (HP:0000431)**
- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Wide nasal bridge is a *common* dysmorphic feature seen in many genetic syndromes and developmental disorders. It is *less specific* but can be informative when combined with other features.

diseases: Congenital Contractures of the Limbs and Face, Hypotonia, and Developmental Delay

hpo_input.name: Global brain atrophy
hpo_input.definition: "Unlocalized atrophy of the brain with decreased total brain matter volume and increased ventricular size." [https://orcid.org/0009-0006-4530-3154]

hpo_input.name: Strabismus
hpo_input.definition: "A misalignment of the eyes so that the visual axes deviate from bifoveal fixation. The classification of strabismus may be based on a number of features including the relative position of the eyes, whether the deviation is latent or manifest, intermittent or constant, concomitant or otherwise and according to the age of onset and the relevance of any associated refractive error." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0986-4123, PMID:26319345]

hpo_input.name: Umbilical hernia
hpo_input.definition: "Protrusion of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall musculature around the umbilicus. Skin and subcutaneous tissue overlie the defect." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Dimple chin
hpo_input.definition: "A persistent midline depression of the skin over the fat pad of the chin." [PMID:19125436]

hpo_input.name: Talipes equinovarus
hpo_input.definition: "Talipes equinovarus (also called clubfoot) typically has four main components: inversion and adduction of the forefoot; inversion of the heel and hindfoot; equinus (limitation of extension) of the ankle and subtalar joint; and internal rotation of the leg." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:32491773]

hpo_input.name: Wide nasal bridge
hpo_input.definition: "Increased breadth of the nasal bridge (and with it, the nasal root)." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:19152422]
synonym: Increased breadth of bridge of nose
Increased width of bridge of nose

hpo_input.name: Full cheeks
hpo_input.definition: "Increased prominence or roundness of soft tissues between zygomata and mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2972-5481]

hpo_input.name: Calcaneovalgus deformity
hpo_input.definition: "This is a postural deformity in which the foot is positioned up against the tibia. The heel (calcaneus) is positioned downward (that is, the ankle is flexed upward), and the heel is turned outward (valgus)." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Foot and ankle bend up toward shin of leg

hpo_input.name: Scoliosis
hpo_input.definition: "The presence of an abnormal lateral curvature of the spine." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Cobb angle greater than ten degrees

hpo_input.name: Short columella
hpo_input.definition: "Reduced distance from the anterior border of the naris to the subnasale." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Abnormal pattern of respiration
hpo_input.definition: "An anomaly of the rhythm or depth of breathing." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Pursed lips
hpo_input.definition: "An abnormality of the appearance of the face caused by constant contraction of the lips leading to a puckered or pursed appearance." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Adducted thumb
hpo_input.definition: "In the resting position, the tip of the thumb is on, or near, the palm, close to the base of the fourth or fifth finger." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6670-9157, PMID:16235349, PMID:19125433]

hpo_input.name: Delayed speech and language development
hpo_input.definition: "A degree of language development that is significantly below the norm for a child of a specified age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Hip dislocation
hpo_input.definition: "Displacement of the femur from its normal location in the hip joint." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Hypotonia
hpo_input.definition: "Hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone (the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle). Even when relaxed, muscles have a continuous and passive partial contraction which provides some resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia thus manifests as diminished resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia is not the same as muscle weakness, although the two conditions can co-exist." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:21418198]

hpo_input.name: Short neck
hpo_input.definition: "Diminished length of the neck." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Micrognathia
hpo_input.definition: "Developmental hypoplasia of the mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Global developmental delay
hpo_input.definition: "A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6410-0882, https://orcid.org/0009-0006-4530-3154]

hpo_input.name: Camptodactyly
hpo_input.definition: "The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fingers or toes cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Permanent flexion of the finger or toe

hpo_input.name: Gastroesophageal reflux
hpo_input.definition: "A condition in which the stomach contents leak backwards from the stomach into the esophagus through the lower esophageal sphincter." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Long philtrum
hpo_input.definition: "Distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Enlarged naris
hpo_input.definition: "Increased aperture of the nostril." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Motor delay
hpo_input.definition: "A type of Developmental delay characterized by a delay in acquiring motor skills." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Delay in development of motor milestones

hpo_input.name: Knee flexion contracture
hpo_input.definition: "A type of knee joint contracture in which the knee is in a fixed bent (flexed) configuration such that it cannot be straightened actively or passively." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:31282072]

Answer the following three questions for each hpo term:
1. Which of these hpo terms are more common and less informative for a specific disease?
2. Which of these hpo terms are rare and informative for a specific disease?
3. Is there a spesific gender or age group that is more likely to have these hpo terms?
search_results:
Here is an analysis of the listed HPO terms regarding their commonality, informativeness for specific diseases, and any gender or age predilections based on the provided information:

---

### 1. Global brain atrophy (HP:0002283)
- **Common and less informative:** Brain atrophy is a relatively common finding in many neurological diseases such as Alzheimer's, stroke, multiple sclerosis, infections, and malnutrition. It is a general sign of brain tissue loss and thus less specific for a particular disease[1][3][7][11].
- **Rare and informative:** Specific patterns like brain hemiatrophy or focal atrophy can be more informative for particular syndromes (e.g., Sturge-Weber syndrome, tuberous sclerosis)[1].
- **Age/gender:** More common with aging and neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., Alzheimer's typically after age 60). Some causes like multiple sclerosis affect women more often[7][11].

---

### 2. Strabismus (HP:0000486)
- **Common and less informative:** Strabismus is a common pediatric eye disorder, often idiopathic or related to refractive errors, and thus less informative alone[2][4][10].
- **Rare and informative:** Strabismus caused by cranial nerve palsies, brain tumors, or syndromic conditions (e.g., Down syndrome, cerebral palsy) is more specific and informative[2][4].
- **Age/gender:** Most commonly develops in infants and young children (by age 3), but can also occur in adults due to neurological or systemic causes[2][4][10][14].

---

### 3. Umbilical hernia (HP:0001537)
- **Common and less informative:** Umbilical hernias are common in infants and often benign; less specific for disease unless associated with syndromes or other anomalies.
- **Rare and informative:** When persistent or associated with other anomalies, it may indicate connective tissue disorders or syndromic conditions.
- **Age/gender:** More common in infants; usually resolves spontaneously in childhood.

---

### 4. Dimple chin (HP:0010751)
- **Common and less informative:** A dimpled chin is a common facial variant, usually benign and not disease-specific.
- **Rare and informative:** Rarely informative unless part of a syndrome with multiple dysmorphic features.
- **Age/gender:** Present from birth; no specific gender predilection.

---

### 5. Talipes equinovarus (clubfoot) (HP:0001762)
- **Common and less informative:** Clubfoot is a relatively common congenital deformity, sometimes isolated and idiopathic.
- **Rare and informative:** When associated with neuromuscular disorders or syndromes, it becomes more informative[1].
- **Age/gender:** Present at birth; no strong gender bias reported.

---

### 6. Wide nasal bridge (HP:0000431)
- **Common and less informative:** A wide nasal bridge is a common facial feature variant.
- **Rare and informative:** When combined with other dysmorphic features, it can be informative for genetic syndromes[4].
- **Age/gender:** Present from birth; no gender predilection.

---

### 7. Full cheeks (HP:0000293)
- **Common and less informative:** Full cheeks are a common facial trait, often benign.
- **Rare and informative:** May be informative if part of a syndrome with other features.
- **Age/gender:** Present from birth; no gender predilection.

---

### 8. Calcaneovalgus deformity (HP:0001848)
- **Common and less informative:** A postural foot deformity often seen in newborns; usually benign and resolves.
- **Rare and informative:** Persistent or severe deformities may indicate neuromuscular or syndromic conditions.
- **Age/gender:** Common in newborns; no gender bias.

---

### 9. Scoliosis (HP:0002650)
- **Common and less informative:** Scoliosis is common in adolescents (idiopathic scoliosis).
- **Rare and informative:** Early-onset or syndromic scoliosis (e.g., neuromuscular disorders) is more informative.
- **Age/gender:** More common in adolescent females for idiopathic scoliosis.

---

### 10. Respiratory insufficiency (HP:0002093)
- **Common and less informative:** Respiratory insufficiency is a common symptom in many diseases; non-specific.
- **Rare and informative:** When due to rare neuromuscular or genetic disorders, it is informative.
- **Age/gender:** Can occur at any age; depends on underlying cause.

---

### 11. Short columella (HP:0002000)
- **Common and less informative:** A facial variant, often benign.
- **Rare and informative:** May be part of syndromic facial dysmorphisms.
- **Age/gender:** Present from birth; no gender bias.

---

### 12. Abnormal pattern of respiration (HP:0002793)
- **Common and less informative:** Seen in many respiratory or neurological conditions; non-specific.
- **Rare and informative:** Specific patterns (e.g., Cheyne-Stokes) can be informative.
- **Age/gender:** Any age; depends on cause.

---

### 13. Pursed lips (HP:0000205)
- **Common and less informative:** Common in chronic respiratory diseases like COPD.
- **Rare and informative:** Rarely informative alone.
- **Age/gender:** More common in adults with respiratory disease.

---

### 14. Adducted thumb (HP:0001181)
- **Common and less informative:** Can be seen in normal variants or minor anomalies.
- **Rare and informative:** When associated with syndromes (e.g., Freeman-Sheldon syndrome), it is informative[1].
- **Age/gender:** Present from birth; no gender bias.

---

### 15. Delayed speech and language development (HP:0000750)
- **Common and less informative:** Common in many developmental disorders; non-specific.
- **Rare and informative:** When combined with other features, can point to specific genetic syndromes.
- **Age/gender:** Children under 5; no strong gender bias but some male predominance in speech delay.

---

### 16. Hip dislocation (HP:0002827)
- **Common and less informative:** Developmental hip dysplasia is relatively common in infants.
- **Rare and informative:** Pathologic dislocations in syndromes or neuromuscular disorders are informative.
- **Age/gender:** More common in infants; females more affected in developmental dysplasia.

---

### 17. Hypotonia (HP:0001252)
- **Common and less informative:** Common in many neuromuscular and genetic disorders; non-specific.
- **Rare and informative:** Severe congenital hypotonia can be informative for specific diagnoses.
- **Age/gender:** Present at birth or early childhood; no gender bias.

---

### 18. Short neck (HP:0000470)
- **Common and less informative:** Common in many syndromes but also seen as a normal variant.
- **Rare and informative:** When combined with other anomalies, it is informative.
- **Age/gender:** Present from birth; no gender bias.

---

### 19. Micrognathia (HP:0000347)
- **Common and less informative:** Common dysmorphic feature in many syndromes.
- **Rare and informative:** Severe micrognathia is informative for syndromes like Pierre Robin sequence.
- **Age/gender:** Present from birth; no gender bias.

---

### 20. Global developmental delay (HP:0001263)
- **Common and less informative:** Common in many pediatric conditions; non-specific.
- **Rare and informative:** When severe or combined with other features, it is informative.
- **Age/gender:** Children under 5; no gender bias.

---

### 21. Camptodactyly (HP:0012385)
- **Common and less informative:** Can be a benign isolated finding.
- **Rare and informative:** When part of syndromes (e.g., distal arthrogryposis), it is informative.
- **Age/gender:** Present from birth; no gender bias.

---

### 22. Gastroesophageal reflux (HP:0002020)
- **Common and less informative:** Very common in infants and adults; non-specific.
- **Rare and informative:** Severe or syndromic GERD can be informative.
- **Age/gender:** Common in infants; no gender bias.

---

### 23. Long philtrum (HP:0000343)
- **Common and less informative:** A facial variant.
- **Rare and informative:** Can be part of syndromes such as fetal alcohol syndrome.
- **Age/gender:** Present from birth; no gender bias.

---

### 24. Enlarged naris (HP:0009931)
- **Common and less informative:** Facial variant.
- **Rare and informative:** When combined with other features, informative.
- **Age/gender:** Present from birth; no gender bias.

---

### 25. Motor delay (HP:0001270)
- **Common and less informative:** Common in many pediatric conditions.
- **Rare and informative:** When severe or syndromic, informative.
- **Age/gender:** Children under 5; no gender bias.

---

### 26. Knee flexion contracture (HP:0006380)
- **Common and less informative:** Common in neuromuscular disorders or after injury.
- **Rare and informative:** When congenital or syndromic, informative.
- **Age/gender:** Any age; no gender bias.

---

**Summary of key points:**

| HPO Term                  | Common & Less Informative                         | Rare & Informative                                   | Age/Gender Predilection                         |
|---------------------------|-------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------|
| Global brain atrophy       | Common in many neurodegenerative diseases        | Specific patterns (hemiatrophy)                      | Older adults; some diseases affect women more  |

| Scoliosis                  | Common adolescent idiopathic                      | Early onset or syndromic                              | Adolescents; females more for idiopathic        |
| Respiratory insufficiency  | Common symptom                                   | Rare neuromuscular causes                             | Any age                                         |
| Short columella            | Common facial variant                             | Syndromic when combined                               | Birth; no gender bias                            |
| Abnormal pattern of respiration | Common symptom                              | Specific patterns informative                          | Any age                                         |
| Pursed lips                | Common in respiratory disease                      | Rarely informative                                    | Adults with respiratory disease                  |
| Adducted thumb             | Common variant                                   | Syndromic when combined                               | Birth; no gender bias                            |

diseases: Congenital Contractures of the Limbs and Face, Hypotonia, and Developmental Delay

hpo_input.name: Metatarsus adductus
hpo_input.definition: "The metatarsals are deviated medially (tibially), that is, the bones in the front half of the foot bend or turn in toward the body." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:19125433]
synonym: Front half of foot turns inward

hpo_input.name: Wide nasal bridge
hpo_input.definition: "Increased breadth of the nasal bridge (and with it, the nasal root)." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:19152422]
synonym: Increased breadth of bridge of nose
Increased width of bridge of nose

hpo_input.name: Micrognathia
hpo_input.definition: "Developmental hypoplasia of the mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Full cheeks
hpo_input.definition: "Increased prominence or roundness of soft tissues between zygomata and mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2972-5481]

hpo_input.name: Rigidity
hpo_input.definition: "Continuous involuntary sustained muscle contraction. When an affected muscle is passively stretched, the degree of resistance remains constant regardless of the rate at which the muscle is stretched. This feature helps to distinguish rigidity from muscle spasticity." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Short neck
hpo_input.definition: "Diminished length of the neck." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Pursed lips
hpo_input.definition: "An abnormality of the appearance of the face caused by constant contraction of the lips leading to a puckered or pursed appearance." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Enlarged naris
hpo_input.definition: "Increased aperture of the nostril." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Motor delay
hpo_input.definition: "A type of Developmental delay characterized by a delay in acquiring motor skills." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Delay in development of motor milestones

hpo_input.name: Esotropia
hpo_input.definition: "A form of strabismus with one or both eyes turned inward ('crossed') to a relatively severe degree, usually defined as 10 diopters or more." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Long philtrum
hpo_input.definition: "Distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Adducted thumb
hpo_input.definition: "In the resting position, the tip of the thumb is on, or near, the palm, close to the base of the fourth or fifth finger." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6670-9157, PMID:16235349, PMID:19125433]

hpo_input.name: Delayed speech and language development
hpo_input.definition: "A degree of language development that is significantly below the norm for a child of a specified age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Gastroesophageal reflux
hpo_input.definition: "A condition in which the stomach contents leak backwards from the stomach into the esophagus through the lower esophageal sphincter." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Inguinal hernia
hpo_input.definition: "Protrusion of the contents of the abdominal cavity through the inguinal canal." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Abnormal pattern of respiration
hpo_input.definition: "An anomaly of the rhythm or depth of breathing." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Hypotonia
hpo_input.definition: "Hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone (the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle). Even when relaxed, muscles have a continuous and passive partial contraction which provides some resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia thus manifests as diminished resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia is not the same as muscle weakness, although the two conditions can co-exist." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:21418198]

hpo_input.name: Global developmental delay
hpo_input.definition: "A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6410-0882, https://orcid.org/0009-0006-4530-3154]

hpo_input.name: Camptodactyly
hpo_input.definition: "The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fingers or toes cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Permanent flexion of the finger or toe

hpo_input.name: Short columella
hpo_input.definition: "Reduced distance from the anterior border of the naris to the subnasale." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Strabismus
hpo_input.definition: "A misalignment of the eyes so that the visual axes deviate from bifoveal fixation. The classification of strabismus may be based on a number of features including the relative position of the eyes, whether the deviation is latent or manifest, intermittent or constant, concomitant or otherwise and according to the age of onset and the relevance of any associated refractive error." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0986-4123, PMID:26319345]

| HPO Term (ID & Name) | More Common & Less Informative | Rare & Informative | Gender or Age Predilection |
|----------------------|-------------------------------|-------------------|---------------------------|
| HP:0001840 Metatarsus adductus | **Common** congenital foot deformity in infants; often self-resolving and seen in many children; less informative alone for specific diseases[1][2][3][6]. | Severe, rigid forms requiring surgery are less common and more informative for underlying syndromes or neuromuscular conditions[2][5]. | Primarily seen in **newborns and infants**; more common in **firstborn children**; no specific gender bias reported[1][6]. |
| HP:0000431 Wide nasal bridge | Common facial feature in many syndromes and normal variants; less specific alone[HPO definition]. | When combined with other dysmorphic features, can be informative for syndromic diagnoses[HPO]. | No specific gender or age predilection; often noted in pediatric dysmorphology assessments. |
| HP:0000347 Micrognathia | Common in various congenital syndromes; somewhat informative especially when severe[HPO]. | Severe micrognathia is rare and highly informative for syndromes like Pierre Robin sequence[HPO]. | Typically identified in **infants and children**; no clear gender bias. |
| HP:0000293 Full cheeks | Common and nonspecific facial feature; less informative alone[HPO]. | Rarely informative unless part of a syndrome with other features[HPO]. | No specific gender or age predilection. |
| HP:0002063 Rigidity | Common in neurological disorders but nonspecific; less informative alone[HPO]. | When present with other neurological signs, can be informative for Parkinsonian or extrapyramidal syndromes[HPO]. | More common in **adults** with neurodegenerative diseases; can occur at any age depending on etiology. |
| HP:0000470 Short neck | Common in many syndromes and chromosomal abnormalities; less specific alone[HPO]. | When combined with other features, informative for syndromes like Turner syndrome or Klippel-Feil[HPO]. | Noted in **children and adults** with congenital anomalies; no gender bias except Turner syndrome (female). |
| HP:0000205 Pursed lips | Common facial expression abnormality; less informative alone[HPO]. | May be informative in neuromuscular or metabolic diseases affecting facial muscles[HPO]. | No specific gender or age predilection. |

| HP:0000565 Esotropia | Common form of strabismus; less specific alone[HPO]. | Severe or congenital esotropia can be informative for neurological or syndromic conditions[HPO]. | More common in **children**; no clear gender bias. |
| HP:0000343 Long philtrum | Common facial feature in many syndromes; less specific alone[HPO]. | When combined with other features, informative for syndromes such as fetal alcohol syndrome[HPO]. | No specific gender or age predilection. |
| HP:0001181 Adducted thumb | Less common, more specific deformity; informative for syndromes like Rubinstein-Taybi[HPO]. | Rare and informative for specific genetic syndromes[HPO]. | Usually identified in **infants and children**; no gender bias. |
| HP:0000750 Delayed speech and language development | Common developmental concern; less specific alone[HPO]. | Severe or isolated delays can be informative for neurodevelopmental disorders[HPO]. | Primarily in **young children**; no gender bias. |
| HP:0002093 Respiratory insufficiency | Common in many diseases; less specific alone[HPO]. | Severe or early-onset respiratory insufficiency can be informative for neuromuscular or pulmonary diseases[HPO]. | Can occur at any age depending on cause; no gender bias. |
| HP:0002020 Gastroesophageal reflux | Common condition; less specific alone[HPO]. | Severe or early-onset GERD can be informative for metabolic or neurological disorders[HPO]. | More frequent in **infants and elderly**; no gender bias. |
| HP:0000023 Inguinal hernia | Common surgical condition; less specific alone[HPO]. | Rare bilateral or syndromic hernias can be informative[HPO]. | More common in **male infants and children**. |
| HP:0002793 Abnormal pattern of respiration | Common in various conditions; less specific alone[HPO]. | Informative when part of neuromuscular or central nervous system disorders[HPO]. | Can occur at any age; no gender bias. |
| HP:0001252 Hypotonia | Common in many pediatric conditions; less specific alone[HPO]. | Severe or persistent hypotonia is informative for neuromuscular or genetic disorders[HPO]. | Primarily in **infants and young children**; no gender bias. |
| HP:0001263 Global developmental delay | Common pediatric diagnosis; less specific alone[HPO]. | Informative for broad neurodevelopmental disorders[HPO]. | Only used for children **under 5 years**; no gender bias. |
| HP:0012385 Camptodactyly | Less common, more specific finger deformity; informative for connective tissue or genetic syndromes[HPO]. | Rare and informative for specific syndromes[HPO]. | Usually identified in **children**; no gender bias. |
| HP:0002000 Short columella | Common facial feature in many syndromes; less specific alone[HPO]. | Informative when combined with other facial dysmorphisms[HPO]. | No specific gender or age predilection. |
| HP:0000486 Strabismus | Common eye misalignment; less specific alone[HPO]. | Congenital or severe strabismus can be informative for neurological or syndromic conditions[HPO]. | More common in **children**; no gender bias. |

**Summary for Metatarsus Adductus (HP:0001840):**  
- It is a **common congenital foot deformity** in infants, often resolving spontaneously without treatment[1][2][3][6].  
- Severe or rigid forms that require intervention are **less common and more informative** for underlying syndromes or neuromuscular disorders[2][5].  
- It is primarily seen in **newborns and infants**, more frequently in **firstborn children**, with no clear gender bias[1][6].

For other terms, the pattern is similar: features like wide nasal bridge, short neck, and strabismus are common and less specific alone but become informative when combined with other signs. Rare deformities such as adducted thumb and camptodactyly are more specific and informative. Most developmental delays and muscle tone abnormalities are primarily noted in infants and young children, with no strong gender predilection except for some conditions like inguinal hernia, which is more common in males.

No specific gender predilections are widely reported for most of these terms, except where linked to known syndromes (e.g., Turner syndrome with short neck in females, inguinal hernia more common in males). Age predilection is mostly pediatric, especially infancy and early childhood, reflecting the developmental nature of many of these phenotypes.

| HP:0000023 Inguinal hernia | Common surgical condition; less specific alone[HPO]. | Rare bilateral or syndromic hernias can be informative[HPO]. | More common in **male infants and children**. |
| HP:0002793 Abnormal pattern of respiration | Common in various conditions; less specific alone[HPO]. | Informative when part of neuromuscular or central nervous system disorders[HPO]. | Can occur at any age; no gender bias. |
| HP:0001252 Hypotonia | Common in many pediatric conditions; less specific alone[HPO]. | Severe or persistent hypotonia is informative for neuromuscular or genetic disorders[HPO]. | Primarily in **infants and young children**; no gender bias. |
| HP:0001263 Global developmental delay | Common pediatric diagnosis; less specific alone[HPO]. | Informative for broad neurodevelopmental disorders[HPO]. | Only used for children **under 5 years**; no gender bias. |
| HP:0012385 Camptodactyly | Less common, more specific finger deformity; informative for connective tissue or genetic syndromes[HPO]. | Rare and informative for specific syndromes[HPO]. | Usually identified in **children**; no gender bias. |
| HP:0002000 Short columella | Common facial feature in many syndromes; less specific alone[HPO]. | Informative when combined with other facial dysmorphisms[HPO]. | No specific gender or age predilection. |
| HP:0000486 Strabismus | Common eye misalignment; less specific alone[HPO]. | Congenital or severe strabismus can be informative for neurological or syndromic conditions[HPO]. | More common in **children**; no gender bias. |

**Summary for Metatarsus Adductus (HP:0001840):**  
- It is a **common congenital foot deformity** in infants, often resolving spontaneously without treatment[1][2][3][6].  
- Severe or rigid forms that require intervention are **less common and more informative** for underlying syndromes or neuromuscular disorders[2][5].  
- It is primarily seen in **newborns and infants**, more frequently in **firstborn children**, with no clear gender bias[1][6].

For other terms, the pattern is similar: features like wide nasal bridge, short neck, and strabismus are common and less specific alone but become informative when combined with other signs. Rare deformities such as adducted thumb and camptodactyly are more specific and informative. Most developmental delays and muscle tone abnormalities are primarily noted in infants and young children, with no strong gender predilection except for some conditions like inguinal hernia, which is more common in males.

No specific gender predilections are widely reported for most of these terms, except where linked to known syndromes (e.g., Turner syndrome with short neck in females, inguinal hernia more common in males). Age predilection is mostly pediatric, especially infancy and early childhood, reflecting the developmental nature of many of these phenotypes.
</hpo_info>

    "gender": [gender],
    "ethnicity": [ethnicity] (only if relevant else None),
    "symptoms": [symptoms] (just list some keywords, don't bother writing full sentences!)
}

hpo_input.name: Gastroesophageal reflux
hpo_input.definition: "A condition in which the stomach contents leak backwards from the stomach into the esophagus through the lower esophageal sphincter." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Knee flexion contracture
hpo_input.definition: "A type of knee joint contracture in which the knee is in a fixed bent (flexed) configuration such that it cannot be straightened actively or passively." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:31282072]

hpo_input.name: Delayed speech and language development
hpo_input.definition: "A degree of language development that is significantly below the norm for a child of a specified age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Micrognathia
hpo_input.definition: "Developmental hypoplasia of the mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Full cheeks
hpo_input.definition: "Increased prominence or roundness of soft tissues between zygomata and mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2972-5481]

hpo_input.name: Adducted thumb
hpo_input.definition: "In the resting position, the tip of the thumb is on, or near, the palm, close to the base of the fourth or fifth finger." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6670-9157, PMID:16235349, PMID:19125433]

hpo_input.name: Elbow flexion contracture
hpo_input.definition: "An elbow contracture that limits the ability of the elbow joint to be extended (straightened), meaning that the elbow is fixed in an flexed (bent) position." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Fixed flexion at the elbow joint

hpo_input.name: Global developmental delay
hpo_input.definition: "A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6410-0882, https://orcid.org/0009-0006-4530-3154]

hpo_input.name: Motor delay
hpo_input.definition: "A type of Developmental delay characterized by a delay in acquiring motor skills." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Delay in development of motor milestones

hpo_input.name: Seizure
hpo_input.definition: "A seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterized by a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:15816939]

hpo_input.name: Cerebellar atrophy
hpo_input.definition: "Cerebellar atrophy is defined as a cerebellum with initially normal structures, in a posterior fossa with normal size, which displays enlarged fissures (interfolial spaces) in comparison to the foliae secondary to loss of tissue. Cerebellar atrophy implies irreversible loss of tissue and result from an ongoing progressive disease until a final stage is reached or a single injury, e.g. an intoxication or infectious event." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:12169461, PMID:26331051]

hpo_input.name: Hypotonia
hpo_input.definition: "Hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone (the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle). Even when relaxed, muscles have a continuous and passive partial contraction which provides some resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia thus manifests as diminished resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia is not the same as muscle weakness, although the two conditions can co-exist." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:21418198]

hpo_input.name: Apnea
hpo_input.definition: "Lack of breathing with no movement of the respiratory muscles and no exchange of air in the lungs. This term refers to a disposition to have recurrent episodes of apnea rather than to a single event." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Abnormal pattern of respiration
hpo_input.definition: "An anomaly of the rhythm or depth of breathing." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Drooling
hpo_input.definition: "Habitual flow of saliva out of the mouth." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:15202698]

hpo_input.name: Talipes equinovarus
hpo_input.definition: "Talipes equinovarus (also called clubfoot) typically has four main components: inversion and adduction of the forefoot; inversion of the heel and hindfoot; equinus (limitation of extension) of the ankle and subtalar joint; and internal rotation of the leg." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:32491773]

hpo_input.name: Constipation
hpo_input.definition: "Infrequent or difficult evacuation of feces." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Strabismus
hpo_input.definition: "A misalignment of the eyes so that the visual axes deviate from bifoveal fixation. The classification of strabismus may be based on a number of features including the relative position of the eyes, whether the deviation is latent or manifest, intermittent or constant, concomitant or otherwise and according to the age of onset and the relevance of any associated refractive error." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0986-4123, PMID:26319345]

hpo_input.name: Enlarged naris
hpo_input.definition: "Increased aperture of the nostril." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Long philtrum
hpo_input.definition: "Distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Dimple chin
hpo_input.definition: "A persistent midline depression of the skin over the fat pad of the chin." [PMID:19125436]

hpo_input.name: Camptodactyly
hpo_input.definition: "The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fingers or toes cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Permanent flexion of the finger or toe

hpo_input.name: Wide nasal bridge
hpo_input.definition: "Increased breadth of the nasal bridge (and with it, the nasal root)." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:19152422]
synonym: Increased breadth of bridge of nose
Increased width of bridge of nose

hpo_input.name: Short columella
hpo_input.definition: "Reduced distance from the anterior border of the naris to the subnasale." [PMID:19152422]

Answer the following three questions for each hpo term:
1. Which of these hpo terms are more common and less informative for a specific disease?
2. Which of these hpo terms are rare and informative for a specific disease?
3. Is there a spesific gender or age group that is more likely to have these hpo terms?
search_results:
# Analysis of HPO Terms for Disease Specificity and Clinical Relevance

## Overview

The HPO (Human Phenotype Ontology) terms provided span a wide range of clinical features, from highly specific to non-specific findings. Below is a detailed analysis of each term's diagnostic utility, rarity, and demographic associations.

## Gastroesophageal Reflux (HP:0002020)

**Common and Less Informative:**
Gastroesophageal reflux is a **highly common condition** affecting a significant portion of the general population[1][3]. The condition occurs when the lower esophageal sphincter fails to close properly, allowing stomach contents to leak backward into the esophagus[1]. While it causes characteristic symptoms like heartburn, this finding alone is not specific to any particular disease and can occur as a primary condition or secondary to numerous other disorders[3].

**Demographic Patterns:**
This condition affects individuals across all age groups and genders, though it may be exacerbated during pregnancy[1]. It is particularly common in obese individuals and those with hiatal hernias[1][7].

---

## Knee Flexion Contracture (HP:0006380)

**Rare and Informative:**
Knee flexion contracture is a **more specific finding** that indicates significant underlying pathology[2][4]. This condition represents a fixed bent position of the knee that cannot be straightened actively or passively[2]. While not extremely rare, its presence is highly informative as it suggests specific etiologies such as arthritis, cerebral palsy, post-traumatic deformities, or complications following total knee replacement[6][8].

**Clinical Significance:**
The severity of knee flexion contracture correlates with disease progression. Research indicates that for every degree of flexion contracture present, the risk of requiring knee replacement increases by 6% over three years[4]. Contractures greater than 15 degrees cause measurable biomechanical stress on the knee joint[2].

**Demographic Patterns:**
This condition can affect individuals of various ages but is particularly common in patients with cerebral palsy, those with post-surgical complications, and elderly patients with advanced osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis[6][8].

---

## Delayed Speech and Language Development (HP:0000750)

**Common and Less Informative:**
Speech and language delay is a **relatively common developmental finding** that can result from numerous etiologies including hearing loss, intellectual disability, autism spectrum disorder, cerebral palsy, and many genetic syndromes. While important to identify, this finding alone lacks specificity for any particular disease.

**Demographic Patterns:**
This term applies primarily to **children under five years of age**. Males are statistically more likely to experience speech delays than females, though the reasons for this sex difference remain incompletely understood.

---

## Micrognathia (HP:0000347)

**Rare and Informative:**
Micrognathia (small mandible) is a **more specific craniofacial finding** that is associated with particular genetic syndromes and conditions. This feature is particularly informative when present in combination with other findings, as it appears in conditions such as Pierre Robin sequence, Treacher Collins syndrome, and various genetic syndromes affecting craniofacial development.

**Demographic Patterns:**
Micrognathia is present from birth and affects both males and females equally, though certain genetic syndromes associated with micrognathia may show sex-linked inheritance patterns depending on the specific condition.

---

## Full Cheeks (HP:0000293)

**Common and Less Informative:**
Full or prominent cheeks represent a **non-specific facial feature** that varies widely in the general population based on genetics, body composition, and age. While this finding can be associated with certain conditions (such as Cushing syndrome or certain genetic syndromes), it is too common and variable to be diagnostically informative on its own.

**Demographic Patterns:**
This feature is present across all age groups and genders, though it may be more prominent in children and individuals with higher body weight.

---

## Adducted Thumb (HP:0001181)

**Rare and Informative:**
Adducted thumb (thumb-in-palm deformity) is a **specific and informative finding** that is associated with particular neurological and genetic conditions. This sign is particularly notable in conditions affecting upper motor neurons and in certain genetic syndromes. The presence of bilateral adducted thumbs is especially significant and suggests specific pathology.

**Demographic Patterns:**
This finding is present from birth or early infancy and affects both sexes equally. It is more commonly associated with conditions that manifest in early childhood.

---

## Elbow Flexion Contracture (HP:0002987)

**Rare and Informative:**
Elbow flexion contracture is a **specific finding** indicating fixed limitation of elbow extension. Like knee flexion contractures, this represents significant underlying pathology and is associated with conditions such as cerebral palsy, arthritis, post-traumatic deformities, and prolonged immobilization.

**Demographic Patterns:**
This condition can affect individuals of any age but is particularly common in patients with cerebral palsy and those with chronic neurological conditions.

---

## Global Developmental Delay (HP:0001263)

**Common and Less Informative:**
Global developmental delay is a **relatively common but non-specific finding** that indicates delayed achievement of developmental milestones across multiple domains. This term applies only to children under five years of age and can result from hundreds of different etiologies, making it useful as a screening finding but not specific for any particular disease.

**Demographic Patterns:**
This term is restricted to **children younger than five years of age**. It affects both males and females, though certain genetic conditions associated with developmental delay may show sex-linked patterns.

---

## Motor Delay (HP:0001270)

**Common and Less Informative:**
Motor delay is a **common developmental finding** that is less specific than global developmental delay, as it focuses only on motor skill acquisition. This can result from numerous causes including cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophies, metabolic disorders, and many genetic syndromes.

**Demographic Patterns:**
This applies to **children**, typically identified in the first few years of life. Both males and females are affected, though certain conditions associated with motor delay (such as X-linked muscular dystrophies) show sex-specific patterns.

---

## Seizure (HP:0001250)

**Common but Moderately Informative:**
Seizures are a **relatively common neurological manifestation** that can occur in numerous conditions including epilepsy, metabolic disorders, infections, genetic syndromes, and brain injuries. While seizures indicate significant neurological involvement, they are not specific to any particular disease.

**Demographic Patterns:**
Seizures can occur at any age, though certain types of seizures show age-specific patterns. Some genetic epilepsies show male predominance, while others affect both sexes equally.

---

## Breathing Dysregulation (HP:0005957)

**Rare and Informative:**
Breathing dysregulation is a **specific and potentially informative finding** that suggests involvement of respiratory control centers or neuromuscular systems. This finding is particularly significant when present in combination with other neurological features.

**Demographic Patterns:**
This can occur across age groups but is particularly notable in infants and young children with neurological conditions affecting brainstem function or in patients with neuromuscular disorders.

---

## Cerebellar Atrophy (HP:0001272)

**Rare and Informative:**
Cerebellar atrophy is a **specific neuroimaging finding** that indicates irreversible loss of cerebellar tissue. This is highly informative as it suggests progressive neurological disease or prior injury and is associated with specific conditions such as spinocerebellar ataxias, metabolic disorders, and chronic toxin exposure.

**Demographic Patterns:**
This can develop at any age depending on the underlying etiology, though certain hereditary cerebellar atrophies show age-dependent onset patterns.

---

## Hypotonia (HP:0001252)
