hpo_input.name: Abnormal pattern of respiration
hpo_input.definition: "An anomaly of the rhythm or depth of breathing." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Wide nasal bridge
hpo_input.definition: "Increased breadth of the nasal bridge (and with it, the nasal root)." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:19152422]
synonym: Increased breadth of bridge of nose
Increased width of bridge of nose

hpo_input.name: Enlarged naris
hpo_input.definition: "Increased aperture of the nostril." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Short columella
hpo_input.definition: "Reduced distance from the anterior border of the naris to the subnasale." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Micrognathia
hpo_input.definition: "Developmental hypoplasia of the mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Pursed lips
hpo_input.definition: "An abnormality of the appearance of the face caused by constant contraction of the lips leading to a puckered or pursed appearance." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Dimple chin
hpo_input.definition: "A persistent midline depression of the skin over the fat pad of the chin." [PMID:19125436]

hpo_input.name: Full cheeks
hpo_input.definition: "Increased prominence or roundness of soft tissues between zygomata and mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2972-5481]

hpo_input.name: Camptodactyly
hpo_input.definition: "The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fingers or toes cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Permanent flexion of the finger or toe

hpo_input.name: Adducted thumb
hpo_input.definition: "In the resting position, the tip of the thumb is on, or near, the palm, close to the base of the fourth or fifth finger." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6670-9157, PMID:16235349, PMID:19125433]

hpo_input.name: Hip contracture
hpo_input.definition: "Lack of full passive range of motion (restrictions in flexion, extension, or other movements) of the hip joint resulting from structural changes of non-bony tissues, such as muscles, tendons, ligaments, joint capsules and/or skin." [PMID:16214063, PMID:24975760, PMID:31282072]

hpo_input.name: Elbow flexion contracture
hpo_input.definition: "An elbow contracture that limits the ability of the elbow joint to be extended (straightened), meaning that the elbow is fixed in an flexed (bent) position." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Fixed flexion at the elbow joint

hpo_input.name: Knee flexion contracture
hpo_input.definition: "A type of knee joint contracture in which the knee is in a fixed bent (flexed) configuration such that it cannot be straightened actively or passively." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:31282072]

hpo_input.name: Short neck
hpo_input.definition: "Diminished length of the neck." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Global developmental delay
hpo_input.definition: "A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6410-0882, https://orcid.org/0009-0006-4530-3154]

hpo_input.name: Delayed speech and language development
hpo_input.definition: "A degree of language development that is significantly below the norm for a child of a specified age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Motor delay
hpo_input.definition: "A type of Developmental delay characterized by a delay in acquiring motor skills." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Delay in development of motor milestones

hpo_input.name: Seizure
hpo_input.definition: "A seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterized by a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:15816939]

hpo_input.name: Fever
hpo_input.definition: "Body temperature elevated above the normal range." [https://orcid.org/0009-0006-4530-3154, PMID:9759682]

hpo_input.name: Drooling
hpo_input.definition: "Habitual flow of saliva out of the mouth." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:15202698]

hpo_input.name: Gastroesophageal reflux
hpo_input.definition: "A condition in which the stomach contents leak backwards from the stomach into the esophagus through the lower esophageal sphincter." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Constipation
hpo_input.definition: "Infrequent or difficult evacuation of feces." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

Answer the following three questions for each hpo term:
1. Which of these hpo terms are more common and less informative for a specific disease?
2. Which of these hpo terms are rare and informative for a specific disease?
3. Is there a spesific gender or age group that is more likely to have these hpo terms?
search_results:
Here is a detailed analysis of the provided Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) terms regarding their commonality, informativeness for specific diseases, and any known gender or age predilections:

---

### 1. Abnormal pattern of respiration (HP:0002793)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Abnormal respiratory patterns, including hyperventilation, hypoventilation, Kussmaul breathing, and Biot respirations, are relatively common symptoms seen across a broad range of conditions such as anxiety, metabolic acidosis (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis), neuromuscular diseases, and respiratory disorders[1][3][6]. Because these patterns occur in many diseases, they are **common but less specific** and thus less informative for pinpointing a specific diagnosis.

- **Rare & Informative:**  
  Certain specific abnormal patterns like Kussmaul breathing or Biot respirations are more **rare and highly informative**, often indicating severe metabolic acidosis or brainstem injury, respectively[3][5].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  These patterns can occur in all age groups depending on the underlying cause. For example, hyperventilation syndrome is common in adults with anxiety, while hypoventilation syndromes may be seen in neuromuscular diseases affecting all ages[1][3]. No strong gender predilection is noted.

---

### 2. Wide nasal bridge (HP:0000431)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  A wide nasal bridge is a **common craniofacial feature** seen in many genetic syndromes and developmental disorders but is not highly specific alone[PMID:19152422]. It is often noted in syndromes like Down syndrome or certain skeletal dysplasias.

- **Rare & Informative:**  
  When combined with other dysmorphic features, it becomes more **informative** for specific syndromes.

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Present from birth and observed in pediatric populations; no specific gender bias reported.

---

### 3. Enlarged naris (HP:0009931)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Enlarged nostrils are a **less common but recognizable facial feature** that can be part of certain syndromes affecting craniofacial development[PMID:19152422]. Alone, it is moderately informative.

- **Rare & Informative:**  
  More informative when seen with other facial anomalies.

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Congenital feature, no known gender predilection.

---

### 4. Short columella (HP:0002000)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  A short columella is a **relatively rare and specific craniofacial feature** that can help narrow down diagnoses in syndromic contexts[PMID:19152422].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Congenital; no gender predilection.

---

### 5. Micrognathia (HP:0000347)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Micrognathia is a **common and highly informative feature** in many congenital syndromes (e.g., Pierre Robin sequence, Treacher Collins syndrome) and is often a key diagnostic clue[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Present at birth; no strong gender bias.

---

### 6. Pursed lips (HP:0000205)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Pursed lips are a **common facial sign** often seen in chronic respiratory diseases like COPD but are **less informative** for specific genetic diseases[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  More common in adults with chronic lung disease; no gender bias.

---

### 7. Dimple chin (HP:0010751)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Dimple chin is a **common normal variant** or familial trait and is **less informative** diagnostically[PMID:19125436].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Seen in all ages; no gender predilection.

---

### 8. Full cheeks (HP:0000293)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Full cheeks are a **common and nonspecific feature**, often seen in normal variation or obesity, and thus **less informative**[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2972-5481].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  No specific age or gender predilection.

---

### 9. Camptodactyly (HP:0012385)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Camptodactyly is a **relatively rare and informative feature**, often associated with connective tissue disorders or syndromes affecting limb development[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Usually congenital or early childhood onset; no strong gender bias.

---

### 10. Adducted thumb (HP:0001181)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Adducted thumbs are **rare and highly informative**, often seen in genetic syndromes such as X-linked hydrocephalus or arthrogryposis[PMID:16235349].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Congenital; some conditions may have gender bias (e.g., X-linked disorders).

---

### 11. Hip contracture (HP:0003273)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Hip contractures are **common in neuromuscular and orthopedic disorders** but are **less specific** for a particular disease[PMID:16214063].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  More common in children with cerebral palsy or adults with prolonged immobility; no gender bias.

---

### 12. Elbow flexion contracture (HP:0002987)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Similar to hip contracture, it is **common in neuromuscular conditions** and **less informative** alone[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Seen in pediatric and adult populations with neuromuscular disease; no gender bias.

---

### 13. Knee flexion contracture (HP:0006380)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Common in chronic neuromuscular or orthopedic conditions; **less specific**[PMID:31282072].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  No specific gender or age bias.

---

### 14. Short neck (HP:0000470)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Short neck is a **common dysmorphic feature** in several syndromes (e.g., Turner syndrome) and can be **informative** when combined with other features[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Present from birth; Turner syndrome affects females only, so gender may be relevant in some contexts.

---

### 15. Global developmental delay (HP:0001263)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Global developmental delay (GDD) is a **common but highly informative feature** in pediatric neurology, indicating broad neurological impairment[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6410-0882].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Diagnosed in children under 5 years; no gender bias.

---

### 16. Delayed speech and language development (HP:0000750)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Common in many developmental disorders; **informative when combined with other neurological signs**[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Pediatric onset; some studies suggest higher prevalence in males.

---

### 17. Motor delay (HP:0001270)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Common in many neurodevelopmental disorders; **informative especially in early childhood**[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Pediatric; no strong gender bias.

---

### 18. Seizure (HP:0001250)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Seizures are **common neurological events** but can be **highly informative** for specific epilepsy syndromes or metabolic disorders[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Can occur at any age; some epilepsy syndromes have gender predilections.

---

### 19. Fever (HP:0001945)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Fever is a **very common symptom** and **non-specific**, thus less informative diagnostically[PMID:9759682].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Occurs in all ages and genders.

---

### 20. Drooling (HP:0002307)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Drooling is **common in neurological or oromotor disorders** but is **less specific**[PMID:15202698].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  More common in children with developmental delay or adults with neurological impairment; no gender bias.

---

### 21. Gastroesophageal reflux (HP:0002020)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  GERD is **common in general population and in many syndromes**; **less specific** alone[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Can affect all ages; more common in infants and elderly.

---

### 22. Constipation (HP:0002019)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Very common symptom; **non-specific and less informative**[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Affects all ages; slightly more common in females.

---

### Summary Table

| HPO Term                     | Common & Less Informative                         | Rare & Informative                         | Gender/Age Predilection                          |
|-----------------------------|-------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------|
| Abnormal pattern of respiration | Common in many diseases, less specific          | Kussmaul, Biot breathing patterns          | All ages, no strong gender bias                  |

epicrisis_prompts:
You are a medical expert helping professors to prepare a mock clinical trial for their students.
In this sample, there is a list of target hpo terms. Your job is to prepare a mock clinical epicrisis for this sample.

You're given the following information about the target hpo terms:
<hpo_info>
Here is a detailed analysis of the provided Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) terms regarding their commonality, informativeness for specific diseases, and any known gender or age predilections:

---

### 1. Abnormal pattern of respiration (HP:0002793)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Abnormal respiratory patterns, including hyperventilation, hypoventilation, Kussmaul breathing, and Biot respirations, are relatively common symptoms seen across a broad range of conditions such as anxiety, metabolic acidosis (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis), neuromuscular diseases, and respiratory disorders[1][3][6]. Because these patterns occur in many diseases, they are **common but less specific** and thus less informative for pinpointing a specific diagnosis.

- **Rare & Informative:**  
  Certain specific abnormal patterns like Kussmaul breathing or Biot respirations are more **rare and highly informative**, often indicating severe metabolic acidosis or brainstem injury, respectively[3][5].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  These patterns can occur in all age groups depending on the underlying cause. For example, hyperventilation syndrome is common in adults with anxiety, while hypoventilation syndromes may be seen in neuromuscular diseases affecting all ages[1][3]. No strong gender predilection is noted.

---

### 2. Wide nasal bridge (HP:0000431)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  A wide nasal bridge is a **common craniofacial feature** seen in many genetic syndromes and developmental disorders but is not highly specific alone[PMID:19152422]. It is often noted in syndromes like Down syndrome or certain skeletal dysplasias.

- **Rare & Informative:**  
  When combined with other dysmorphic features, it becomes more **informative** for specific syndromes.

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Present from birth and observed in pediatric populations; no specific gender bias reported.

---

### 3. Enlarged naris (HP:0009931)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Enlarged nostrils are a **less common but recognizable facial feature** that can be part of certain syndromes affecting craniofacial development[PMID:19152422]. Alone, it is moderately informative.

- **Rare & Informative:**  
  More informative when seen with other facial anomalies.

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Congenital feature, no known gender predilection.

---

### 4. Short columella (HP:0002000)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  A short columella is a **relatively rare and specific craniofacial feature** that can help narrow down diagnoses in syndromic contexts[PMID:19152422].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Congenital; no gender predilection.

---

### 5. Micrognathia (HP:0000347)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Micrognathia is a **common and highly informative feature** in many congenital syndromes (e.g., Pierre Robin sequence, Treacher Collins syndrome) and is often a key diagnostic clue[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Present at birth; no strong gender bias.

---

### 6. Pursed lips (HP:0000205)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Pursed lips are a **common facial sign** often seen in chronic respiratory diseases like COPD but are **less informative** for specific genetic diseases[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  More common in adults with chronic lung disease; no gender bias.

---

### 7. Dimple chin (HP:0010751)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Dimple chin is a **common normal variant** or familial trait and is **less informative** diagnostically[PMID:19125436].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Seen in all ages; no gender predilection.

---

### 8. Full cheeks (HP:0000293)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Full cheeks are a **common and nonspecific feature**, often seen in normal variation or obesity, and thus **less informative**[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2972-5481].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  No specific age or gender predilection.

---

### 9. Camptodactyly (HP:0012385)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Camptodactyly is a **relatively rare and informative feature**, often associated with connective tissue disorders or syndromes affecting limb development[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Usually congenital or early childhood onset; no strong gender bias.

---

### 10. Adducted thumb (HP:0001181)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Adducted thumbs are **rare and highly informative**, often seen in genetic syndromes such as X-linked hydrocephalus or arthrogryposis[PMID:16235349].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Congenital; some conditions may have gender bias (e.g., X-linked disorders).

---

### 11. Hip contracture (HP:0003273)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Hip contractures are **common in neuromuscular and orthopedic disorders** but are **less specific** for a particular disease[PMID:16214063].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  More common in children with cerebral palsy or adults with prolonged immobility; no gender bias.

---

### 12. Elbow flexion contracture (HP:0002987)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Similar to hip contracture, it is **common in neuromuscular conditions** and **less informative** alone[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Seen in pediatric and adult populations with neuromuscular disease; no gender bias.

---

### 13. Knee flexion contracture (HP:0006380)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Common in chronic neuromuscular or orthopedic conditions; **less specific**[PMID:31282072].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  No specific gender or age bias.

---

### 14. Short neck (HP:0000470)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Short neck is a **common dysmorphic feature** in several syndromes (e.g., Turner syndrome) and can be **informative** when combined with other features[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Present from birth; Turner syndrome affects females only, so gender may be relevant in some contexts.

---

### 15. Global developmental delay (HP:0001263)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Global developmental delay (GDD) is a **common but highly informative feature** in pediatric neurology, indicating broad neurological impairment[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6410-0882].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Diagnosed in children under 5 years; no gender bias.

---

### 16. Delayed speech and language development (HP:0000750)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Common in many developmental disorders; **informative when combined with other neurological signs**[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Pediatric onset; some studies suggest higher prevalence in males.

---

### 17. Motor delay (HP:0001270)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Common in many neurodevelopmental disorders; **informative especially in early childhood**[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Pediatric; no strong gender bias.

---

### 18. Seizure (HP:0001250)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Seizures are **common neurological events** but can be **highly informative** for specific epilepsy syndromes or metabolic disorders[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Can occur at any age; some epilepsy syndromes have gender predilections.

---

### 19. Fever (HP:0001945)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Fever is a **very common symptom** and **non-specific**, thus less informative diagnostically[PMID:9759682].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Occurs in all ages and genders.

---

### 20. Drooling (HP:0002307)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Drooling is **common in neurological or oromotor disorders** but is **less specific**[PMID:15202698].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  More common in children with developmental delay or adults with neurological impairment; no gender bias.

---

### 21. Gastroesophageal reflux (HP:0002020)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  GERD is **common in general population and in many syndromes**; **less specific** alone[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Can affect all ages; more common in infants and elderly.

---

### 22. Constipation (HP:0002019)

- **Commonality & Informativeness:**  
  Very common symptom; **non-specific and less informative**[https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199].

- **Gender/Age Predilection:**  
  Affects all ages; slightly more common in females.

hpo_input.name: Full cheeks
hpo_input.definition: "Increased prominence or roundness of soft tissues between zygomata and mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2972-5481]

hpo_input.name: Wide nasal bridge
hpo_input.definition: "Increased breadth of the nasal bridge (and with it, the nasal root)." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:19152422]
synonym: Increased breadth of bridge of nose
Increased width of bridge of nose

hpo_input.name: Enlarged naris
hpo_input.definition: "Increased aperture of the nostril." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Short columella
hpo_input.definition: "Reduced distance from the anterior border of the naris to the subnasale." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Camptodactyly
hpo_input.definition: "The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fingers or toes cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Permanent flexion of the finger or toe

hpo_input.name: Micrognathia
hpo_input.definition: "Developmental hypoplasia of the mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Umbilical hernia
hpo_input.definition: "Protrusion of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall musculature around the umbilicus. Skin and subcutaneous tissue overlie the defect." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Gastroesophageal reflux
hpo_input.definition: "A condition in which the stomach contents leak backwards from the stomach into the esophagus through the lower esophageal sphincter." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Hypotonia
hpo_input.definition: "Hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone (the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle). Even when relaxed, muscles have a continuous and passive partial contraction which provides some resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia thus manifests as diminished resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia is not the same as muscle weakness, although the two conditions can co-exist." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:21418198]

hpo_input.name: Motor delay
hpo_input.definition: "A type of Developmental delay characterized by a delay in acquiring motor skills." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Delay in development of motor milestones

hpo_input.name: Delayed speech and language development
hpo_input.definition: "A degree of language development that is significantly below the norm for a child of a specified age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Global developmental delay
hpo_input.definition: "A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6410-0882, https://orcid.org/0009-0006-4530-3154]

hpo_input.name: Short neck
hpo_input.definition: "Diminished length of the neck." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Adducted thumb
hpo_input.definition: "In the resting position, the tip of the thumb is on, or near, the palm, close to the base of the fourth or fifth finger." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6670-9157, PMID:16235349, PMID:19125433]

hpo_input.name: Lumbar hyperlordosis
hpo_input.definition: "An abnormal accentuation of the inward curvature of the spine in the lumbar region." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Excessive inward curvature of lower spine

hpo_input.name: Calcaneovalgus deformity
hpo_input.definition: "This is a postural deformity in which the foot is positioned up against the tibia. The heel (calcaneus) is positioned downward (that is, the ankle is flexed upward), and the heel is turned outward (valgus)." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Foot and ankle bend up toward shin of leg

search_results:
# Analysis of HPO Terms: Specificity and Clinical Significance

## Overview of Term Categories

Based on the search results and clinical literature, these HPO terms can be stratified by their diagnostic utility and specificity to particular genetic syndromes.

## Common and Less Informative Terms

**Full cheeks (HP:0000293)**, **delayed speech and language development (HP:0000750)**, **global developmental delay (HP:0001263)**, and **hypotonia (HP:0001252)** are relatively common features across multiple neurodevelopmental and genetic disorders, making them less specific for diagnosis.

Full cheeks appear as a "very frequent" feature in 1p21.3 microdeletion syndrome and as a "frequent" feature in frontometaphyseal dysplasia[1][3]. However, this feature is nonspecific and can occur in various genetic conditions. Similarly, global developmental delay and speech delay are nearly universal findings in neurodevelopmental disorders, with global developmental delay present in 98% of Snijders BlokCampeau syndrome cases and speech disorder/delay in 92%[5]. These features lack discriminatory power because they occur across diverse genetic etiologies.

**Motor delay (HP:0001270)**, **short neck (HP:0000470)**, and **gastroesophageal reflux (HP:0002020)** are also relatively nonspecific and can be secondary manifestations of various conditions rather than primary diagnostic indicators.

## Rare and Highly Informative Terms

**Wide nasal bridge (HP:0000431)** and **short columella (HP:0002000)** are more specific facial features that can help narrow differential diagnoses. Wide nasal bridge is documented as a "very frequent" feature in frontometaphyseal dysplasia[3] and appears in frontonasal dysplasia, where the nose may be "unusually flat and broad"[8]. These features, when combined with other dysmorphic characteristics, provide stronger diagnostic clues.

**Micrognathia (HP:0000347)** is a distinctive feature appearing as "frequent" in both 1p21.3 microdeletion syndrome and frontometaphyseal dysplasia[1][3], making it more informative than general developmental delay when present in combination with other features.

**Camptodactyly (HP:0012385)** and **adducted thumb (HP:0001181)** are skeletal-specific features that, when present, suggest particular genetic syndromes. These hand and finger abnormalities are more specific indicators of certain skeletal dysplasias and neuromuscular conditions.

**Calcaneovalgus deformity (HP:0001848)** and **lumbar hyperlordosis (HP:0002938)** are relatively specific orthopedic findings that, when combined with other features, can help identify particular genetic conditions.

**Umbilical hernia (HP:0001537)** and **enlarged naris (HP:0009931)** are moderately specific features that appear in particular syndrome clusters.

## Gender and Age-Related Patterns

The search results do not provide explicit information regarding gender-specific prevalence for most of these HPO terms. However, some clinical observations can be noted:

**Age-related considerations**: Global developmental delay, motor delay, and delayed speech and language development are specifically defined as features relevant to children younger than five years of age[1]. These terms become less applicable as children mature, even if developmental deficits persist. Facial dysmorphic features like full cheeks, micrognathia, and wide nasal bridge may become less pronounced or more apparent with age, as noted in Noonan syndrome where "distinct features become less clear in adults"[10].

**Gender-specific features**: Frontonasal dysplasia-2 specifically notes that "males with this form often have genital abnormalities, such as absence of one or both testes from the scrotum (cryptorchidism)"[8], indicating sex-specific manifestations for certain conditions. However, most of the HPO terms listed do not show clear gender predilection in the available literature.

**Developmental stage sensitivity**: Features like hypotonia and motor delay are most apparent during infancy and early childhood, while skeletal deformities like camptodactyly and calcaneovalgus deformity may be present from birth or early infancy but may improve or worsen with age depending on the underlying condition.

diseases: Congenital Contractures of the Limbs and Face, Hypotonia, and Developmental Delay

hpo_input.name: Talipes equinovarus
hpo_input.definition: "Talipes equinovarus (also called clubfoot) typically has four main components: inversion and adduction of the forefoot; inversion of the heel and hindfoot; equinus (limitation of extension) of the ankle and subtalar joint; and internal rotation of the leg." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:32491773]

hpo_input.name: Abnormal pattern of respiration
hpo_input.definition: "An anomaly of the rhythm or depth of breathing." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Edema
hpo_input.definition: "An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin, or in one or more cavities of the body." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Hypoventilation
hpo_input.definition: "A reduction in the amount of air transported into the pulmonary alveoli by breathing, leading to hypercapnia (increase in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide)." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Motor delay
hpo_input.definition: "A type of Developmental delay characterized by a delay in acquiring motor skills." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Delay in development of motor milestones

hpo_input.name: Delayed speech and language development
hpo_input.definition: "A degree of language development that is significantly below the norm for a child of a specified age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Global developmental delay
hpo_input.definition: "A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6410-0882, https://orcid.org/0009-0006-4530-3154]

hpo_input.name: Hip contracture
hpo_input.definition: "Lack of full passive range of motion (restrictions in flexion, extension, or other movements) of the hip joint resulting from structural changes of non-bony tissues, such as muscles, tendons, ligaments, joint capsules and/or skin." [PMID:16214063, PMID:24975760, PMID:31282072]

hpo_input.name: Adducted thumb
hpo_input.definition: "In the resting position, the tip of the thumb is on, or near, the palm, close to the base of the fourth or fifth finger." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6670-9157, PMID:16235349, PMID:19125433]

hpo_input.name: Camptodactyly
hpo_input.definition: "The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fingers or toes cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Permanent flexion of the finger or toe

hpo_input.name: Full cheeks
hpo_input.definition: "Increased prominence or roundness of soft tissues between zygomata and mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2972-5481]

hpo_input.name: Long philtrum
hpo_input.definition: "Distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Short columella
hpo_input.definition: "Reduced distance from the anterior border of the naris to the subnasale." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Enlarged naris
hpo_input.definition: "Increased aperture of the nostril." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Wide nasal bridge
hpo_input.definition: "Increased breadth of the nasal bridge (and with it, the nasal root)." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:19152422]
synonym: Increased breadth of bridge of nose
Increased width of bridge of nose

search_results:
Here is the analysis of the listed HPO terms regarding their commonality, informativeness for specific diseases, and any gender or age predilections:

---

### 1. Talipes equinovarus (HP:0001762)  Clubfoot

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Clubfoot is a relatively common congenital deformity, occurring in about 1 in 1,000 live births. It is more common in boys (about twice as frequent) and affects both feet in roughly half of cases[1][3][6]. Because it is a well-recognized birth defect with a characteristic presentation and treatment, it is considered **common but moderately informative** for specific diseases. It can be isolated or part of syndromes, so its presence alone is not highly specific but still clinically significant.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Clubfoot itself is not rare, but when it occurs as part of syndromic presentations or with unusual features, it becomes more informative diagnostically.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Primarily affects **newborns and infants**, diagnosed at birth or prenatally via ultrasound[1][2]. It is more common in **males**.

---

### 2. Abnormal pattern of respiration (HP:0002793)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  This is a **broad and nonspecific term** describing any atypical breathing rhythm or depth. It is **common and less informative** for specific diseases because many conditions can cause abnormal respiratory patterns.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Not typically rare or specific.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Can occur in any age group and gender, depending on the underlying cause.

---

### 3. Respiratory insufficiency (HP:0002093)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Respiratory insufficiency is a **common clinical feature** in many pulmonary and neuromuscular diseases. It is **less specific** and thus less informative for pinpointing a particular disease.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Not rare; more a clinical state than a diagnostic sign.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Can affect all ages and genders depending on etiology.

---

### 4. Edema (HP:0000969)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Edema is a **very common and nonspecific sign**, resulting from fluid accumulation in tissues due to diverse causes (cardiac, renal, hepatic, lymphatic, etc.). It is **less informative** for specific diseases.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Not rare; common in many conditions.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Occurs across all ages and genders.

---

### 5. Hypoventilation (HP:0002791)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Hypoventilation is a **common respiratory abnormality** in various pulmonary, neuromuscular, or central nervous system disorders. It is **less specific** but can be informative when combined with other signs.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Not rare; more a physiological state than a disease-specific sign.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Can affect any age or gender.

---

### 6. Motor delay (HP:0001270)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Motor delay is a **common developmental concern** in pediatrics and is **less specific** since it can result from many neurological or systemic disorders.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Not rare; more informative when combined with other features.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Primarily in **children**, especially under 5 years.

---

### 7. Delayed speech and language development (HP:0000750)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  This is a **common developmental delay** and **less specific** for particular diseases.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Not rare.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Primarily affects **young children** during language acquisition years.

---

### 8. Global developmental delay (HP:0001263)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Global developmental delay (GDD) is a **common pediatric diagnosis** indicating delay in multiple developmental domains. It is **less specific** but important clinically.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Not rare; more informative when combined with other signs.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Used for children **under 5 years**.

---

### 9. Hip contracture (HP:0003273)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Hip contracture is a **less common and more specific musculoskeletal finding**, often secondary to neuromuscular diseases or prolonged immobility. It can be **informative** for specific conditions affecting muscle or joint function.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Relatively rare and more informative compared to general signs like edema.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Can occur at any age but more common in patients with neuromuscular disorders or after injury.

---

### 10. Adducted thumb (HP:0001181)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Adducted thumb is a **rare and specific physical anomaly** often associated with genetic syndromes (e.g., Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome). It is **informative** for diagnosis.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Yes, considered rare and diagnostically valuable.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Present from birth; no strong gender predilection.

---

### 11. Camptodactyly (HP:0012385)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Camptodactyly is a **relatively rare congenital or acquired finger deformity** and can be **informative** for certain syndromes or isolated conditions.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Yes, relatively rare and informative.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Usually noticed in infancy or childhood; no clear gender bias.

---

### 12. Full cheeks (HP:0000293)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Full cheeks are a **common facial feature** and generally **less informative** unless part of a syndrome.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Not rare; low specificity.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Can be seen in all ages and genders.

---

### 13. Long philtrum (HP:0000343)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  A long philtrum is a **relatively uncommon facial feature** that can be **informative** when associated with syndromes like fetal alcohol syndrome or certain genetic conditions.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Moderately rare and informative in context.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Present from birth; no strong gender bias.

---

### 14. Short columella (HP:0002000)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Short columella is a **less common facial feature** and can be **informative** for syndromic diagnoses.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Relatively rare and informative.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Present from birth; no gender predilection.

---

### 15. Enlarged naris (HP:0009931)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Enlarged naris is a **less common facial anomaly** and can be **informative** for certain syndromes.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Relatively rare and informative.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Present from birth; no gender bias.

---

### 16. Wide nasal bridge (HP:0000431)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Wide nasal bridge is a **common facial feature** seen in many syndromes and normal variants. It is **less specific** but can be informative in a syndromic context.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Common, less informative alone.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Present from birth; no gender predilection.

---

**Summary Table**

| HPO Term                      | Common & Less Informative | Rare & Informative | Gender/Age Predilection                 |
|-------------------------------|--------------------------|--------------------|----------------------------------------|
| Talipes equinovarus (clubfoot) | Yes (common birth defect) | Sometimes (syndromic) | More common in males; infants          |
| Abnormal pattern of respiration | Yes                      | No                 | Any age/gender                         |
| Respiratory insufficiency       | Yes                      | No                 | Any age/gender                         |
| Edema                          | Yes                      | No                 | Any age/gender                         |
| Hypoventilation                | Yes                      | No                 | Any age/gender                         |
| Motor delay                   | Yes                      | No                 | Children (especially <5 years)         |
| Delayed speech/language        | Yes                      | No                 | Children                              |
| Global developmental delay     | Yes                      | No                 | Children <5 years                     |
| Hip contracture                | No                       | Yes                | Any age, often neuromuscular pts      |
| Adducted thumb                | No                       | Yes                | Present from birth; no gender bias    |
| Camptodactyly                 | No                       | Yes                | Infancy/childhood; no gender bias     |
| Full cheeks                   | Yes                      | No                 | All ages/genders                      |
| Long philtrum                 | No                       | Yes                | Present from birth; no gender bias    |
| Short columella               | No                       | Yes                | Present from birth; no gender bias    |
| Enlarged naris                | No                       | Yes                | Present from birth; no gender bias    |
| Wide nasal bridge             | Yes                      | No                 | Present from birth; no gender bias    |

This analysis is based on clinical prevalence, typical diagnostic specificity, and demographic data primarily for clubfoot and general knowledge about developmental and morphological features.

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Not rare; more a clinical state than a diagnostic sign.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Can affect all ages and genders depending on etiology.

---

### 4. Edema (HP:0000969)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Edema is a **very common and nonspecific sign**, resulting from fluid accumulation in tissues due to diverse causes (cardiac, renal, hepatic, lymphatic, etc.). It is **less informative** for specific diseases.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Not rare; common in many conditions.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Occurs across all ages and genders.

---

### 5. Hypoventilation (HP:0002791)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Hypoventilation is a **common respiratory abnormality** in various pulmonary, neuromuscular, or central nervous system disorders. It is **less specific** but can be informative when combined with other signs.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Not rare; more a physiological state than a disease-specific sign.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Can affect any age or gender.

---

### 6. Motor delay (HP:0001270)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Motor delay is a **common developmental concern** in pediatrics and is **less specific** since it can result from many neurological or systemic disorders.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Not rare; more informative when combined with other features.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Primarily in **children**, especially under 5 years.

---

### 7. Delayed speech and language development (HP:0000750)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**

- **Gender/Age Group:**

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Not rare; more informative when combined with other signs.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Used for children **under 5 years**.

---

### 9. Hip contracture (HP:0003273)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Hip contracture is a **less common and more specific musculoskeletal finding**, often secondary to neuromuscular diseases or prolonged immobility. It can be **informative** for specific conditions affecting muscle or joint function.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Relatively rare and more informative compared to general signs like edema.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Can occur at any age but more common in patients with neuromuscular disorders or after injury.

### 10. Adducted thumb (HP:0001181)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Adducted thumb is a **rare and specific physical anomaly** often associated with genetic syndromes (e.g., Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome). It is **informative** for diagnosis.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Yes, considered rare and diagnostically valuable.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Present from birth; no strong gender predilection.

---

### 11. Camptodactyly (HP:0012385)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Yes, relatively rare and informative.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Usually noticed in infancy or childhood; no clear gender bias.

---

### 12. Full cheeks (HP:0000293)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Not rare; low specificity.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Can be seen in all ages and genders.

---

### 13. Long philtrum (HP:0000343)

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Moderately rare and informative in context.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Present from birth; no strong gender bias.

### 14. Short columella (HP:0002000)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Relatively rare and informative.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Present from birth; no gender predilection.

### 15. Enlarged naris (HP:0009931)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**  
  Enlarged naris is a **less common facial anomaly** and can be **informative** for certain syndromes.

- **Rare and Informative?**  
  Relatively rare and informative.

- **Gender/Age Group:**  
  Present from birth; no gender bias.

### 16. Wide nasal bridge (HP:0000431)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**

  Common, less informative alone.

- **Gender/Age Group:**

search_results:
Here is the analysis of the provided HPO terms regarding their commonality, informativeness for specific diseases, and any gender or age predilection:

| HPO Term                      | Commonality & Informativeness                                                                                      | Gender/Age Predilection                                                                                   |
|------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **HP:0001181 Adducted thumb** | Generally considered a less common but not highly specific feature; can be seen in various congenital syndromes but also isolated. It is informative when combined with other features but alone less diagnostic. | No strong gender or age specificity; present at birth or early childhood as a congenital feature.          |
| **HP:0001776 Bilateral talipes equinovarus (Clubfoot)** | Common congenital deformity (~1 in 1,000 births), often bilateral (~50% cases). It is less informative alone since it can be idiopathic or syndromic but is a key clinical sign in many genetic syndromes (e.g., arthrogryposis, trisomy 18). | More common in males (about 2:1 male:female ratio). Present at birth; diagnosis often prenatal or neonatal. |
| **HP:0000343 Long philtrum**  | A relatively common facial feature that is less specific alone but can be informative in syndromes like fetal alcohol syndrome or certain genetic disorders. | No specific gender predilection; typically noted in infancy or childhood as a facial characteristic.       |
| **HP:0010751 Dimple chin**    | A subtle facial feature, relatively common and usually less informative alone; can be a normal variant or part of syndromes. | No strong gender or age specificity; present from birth or early childhood.                                |
| **HP:0000347 Micrognathia**   | A relatively common and highly informative feature in many syndromes (e.g., Pierre Robin sequence, trisomies). It is a key diagnostic sign when present. | No specific gender predilection; congenital, present at birth or detected prenatally.                      |
| **HP:0000205 Pursed lips**    | A less common facial feature, generally less informative alone but may be seen in neuromuscular disorders or syndromes affecting facial muscles. | No clear gender or age predilection; may be congenital or develop early in life depending on underlying cause.|

### Detailed Context

- **Bilateral talipes equinovarus (Clubfoot)** is one of the most common congenital deformities, affecting about 1 in 1,000 live births, with about half of cases bilateral. It is more common in boys (2:1 ratio). While it can occur idiopathically, it is also associated with genetic syndromes such as distal arthrogryposis, myotonic dystrophy, and trisomy 18, making it informative in syndromic contexts[1][2][3][4][5][6][7].

- **Micrognathia** (underdeveloped lower jaw) is a key feature in many genetic syndromes and is highly informative diagnostically. It is congenital and can be detected prenatally or at birth. It is not gender-specific[4].

- **Long philtrum** and **dimple chin** are facial features that are less specific individually but can contribute to syndrome diagnosis when combined with other signs. Long philtrum is noted in conditions like fetal alcohol syndrome[3][4].

- **Adducted thumb** is a congenital hand posture seen in various syndromes but is less common and less specific alone. It is informative when part of a constellation of features[3].

- **Pursed lips** is a less common facial feature, often related to neuromuscular or syndromic conditions affecting facial muscle tone. It is less informative alone and lacks strong demographic predilection[3].

### Summary

- **More common and less informative alone:** Bilateral talipes equinovarus (clubfoot), long philtrum, dimple chin, pursed lips.

- **Rare and more informative for specific diseases:** Micrognathia, adducted thumb.

- **Gender/Age:** Clubfoot is more common in males and present at birth; others have no strong gender bias and are congenital or early childhood features.

hpo_input.name: Polyphagia
hpo_input.definition: "A neurological anomaly with gross overeating associated with an abnormally strong desire or need to eat." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Obesity
hpo_input.definition: "Accumulation of substantial excess body fat." []

hpo_input.name: Hypothyroidism
hpo_input.definition: "Deficiency of thyroid hormone." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Adrenal insufficiency
hpo_input.definition: "Insufficient production of steroid hormones (primarily cortisol) by the adrenal glands." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:11443143]

hpo_input.name: Hypotonia
hpo_input.definition: "Hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone (the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle). Even when relaxed, muscles have a continuous and passive partial contraction which provides some resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia thus manifests as diminished resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia is not the same as muscle weakness, although the two conditions can co-exist." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:21418198]

hpo_input.name: Global developmental delay
hpo_input.definition: "A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6410-0882, https://orcid.org/0009-0006-4530-3154]

hpo_input.name: Tall stature
hpo_input.definition: "A height above that which is expected according to age and gender norms." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Abnormal posterior pituitary morphogenesis
hpo_input.definition: "An abnormality of the neurohypophysis, which is also known as the posterior lobe of the hypophysis." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0538-4547, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Autism
hpo_input.definition: "Autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impaired social interaction and communication, and by restricted and repetitive behavior. Autism begins in childhood. It is marked by the presence of markedly abnormal or impaired development in social interaction and communication and a markedly restricted repertoire of activity and interest. Manifestations of the disorder vary greatly depending on the developmental level and chronological age of the individual (DSM-IV)." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6410-0882]

hpo_input.name: Obstructive sleep apnea
hpo_input.definition: "Obstructive Sleep Apnea is a condition characterized by the obstruction of the airway and pauses in breathing during sleep, which occur multiple times throughout the night. It is related to the relaxation of muscle tone that typically happens during sleep, leading to a partial collapse of the soft tissues in the airway and causing airflow obstruction." [PMID:35609941]

hpo_input.name: Sleep apnea
hpo_input.definition: "An intermittent cessation of airflow at the mouth and nose during sleep is known as sleep apnea. Apneas that last at least 10 seconds are considered significant, but individuals with sleep apnea may experience apneas lasting from 20 seconds up to 2 or 3 minutes. Patients may have up to 15 events per hour of sleep." []

hpo_input.name: Apnea
hpo_input.definition: "Lack of breathing with no movement of the respiratory muscles and no exchange of air in the lungs. This term refers to a disposition to have recurrent episodes of apnea rather than to a single event." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Megalencephaly
hpo_input.definition: "Diffuse enlargement of the entire cerebral hemispheres leading to macrocephaly (with or without overlying cortical dysplasia)." [http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q90573458, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:28658095, PMID:29594439]

hpo_input.name: Skin-picking
hpo_input.definition: "Repetitive and compulsive picking of skin which results in tissue damage." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:20575652]

search_results:
Here is a detailed analysis of the given HPO termsPtosis (HP:0000508), Short stature (HP:0004322), Scoliosis (HP:0002650), Vertebral fusion (HP:0002948), and Camptodactyly of finger (HP:0100490)addressing the three questions for each:

---

### 1. Ptosis (HP:0000508)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**
  - Ptosis is relatively common and can occur in both children and adults. It can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired later in life due to aging, trauma, nerve or muscle disorders (e.g., myasthenia gravis), or surgery[1][3][7].
  - Because ptosis can be caused by many different conditions (myogenic, neurogenic, aponeurotic, mechanical, traumatic), it is considered **less informative** by itself for diagnosing a specific disease unless accompanied by other signs or a known syndrome[7].
  
- **Rarity and Informativeness:**
  - Rare forms of ptosis may be associated with specific genetic or neuromuscular disorders (e.g., congenital myasthenic syndromes, Horner syndrome, neurofibromatosis type 1 with eyelid tumors)[3][7].
  - In such contexts, ptosis becomes **more informative** as a diagnostic clue for these rare diseases.
  
- **Gender or Age Predilection:**
  - Ptosis can affect *all ages* but congenital ptosis is diagnosed in children, while acquired ptosis is more common in older adults due to muscle aging or nerve damage[1][3][7].
  - No strong gender predilection is reported for ptosis.

---

### 2. Short Stature (HP:0004322)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**
  - Short stature is a **common phenotype**, affecting about 2.5% of children (below 3rd percentile height for age and gender)[2][6][8].
  - It is **less informative** alone because it is a nonspecific sign seen in many conditions, including familial short stature, nutritional deficiencies, endocrine disorders, and chronic diseases[2][6].
  
- **Rarity and Informativeness:**
  - Short stature due to **monogenic genetic defects** (e.g., mutations in GH1, GHSR, ACAN genes) is rarer but highly informative for specific diagnoses[2][4].
  - Identification of genetic causes can reclassify many cases previously labeled as idiopathic short stature, making it a valuable diagnostic feature in these contexts.
  
- **Gender or Age Predilection:**
  - Short stature is defined relative to age and gender norms, so it applies to all children.
  - Familial short stature is common and inherited without other abnormalities[6].
  - No specific gender bias; it affects both males and females.

---

### 3. Scoliosis (HP:0002650)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**
  - Scoliosis, defined as an abnormal lateral curvature of the spine (Cobb angle >10 degrees), is relatively common in the general population and often idiopathic[16].
  - It is **less informative** alone because idiopathic scoliosis is frequent and nonspecific.
  
- **Rarity and Informativeness:**
  - Scoliosis associated with syndromic or congenital conditions (e.g., skeletal dysplasias, connective tissue disorders) is rarer and thus **more informative** for specific diseases.
  
- **Gender or Age Predilection:**
  - Idiopathic scoliosis typically appears in adolescence, with a higher prevalence in females.
  - Congenital scoliosis can be diagnosed in infancy or early childhood.

---

### 4. Vertebral Fusion (HP:0002948)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**
  - Vertebral fusion is a **rare developmental defect** leading to fusion of adjacent vertebrae[4].
  - It is **highly informative** for specific congenital syndromes or skeletal dysplasias when present.
  
- **Rarity and Informativeness:**
  - Because vertebral fusion is uncommon and usually congenital, it serves as a strong diagnostic clue for particular genetic or developmental disorders.
  
- **Gender or Age Predilection:**
  - Typically diagnosed in infants or children during evaluation for spinal abnormalities.
  - No clear gender predilection.

---

### 5. Camptodactyly of Finger (HP:0100490)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**
  - Camptodactyly (permanent flexion contracture of finger joints) is relatively rare and often congenital or associated with connective tissue disorders[HP definition].
  - It is **more informative** for specific syndromes or genetic conditions involving joint contractures.
  
- **Rarity and Informativeness:**
  - Its presence can help differentiate syndromic causes of contractures versus acquired causes.
  
- **Gender or Age Predilection:**
  - Usually identified in childhood.
  - No strong gender bias reported.

---

### Summary Table

| HPO Term               | Common & Less Informative for Disease                 | Rare & More Informative for Disease                      | Gender/Age Predilection                          |
|-----------------------|------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------|
| **Ptosis** (HP:0000508)         | Common in general population; caused by many conditions | Rare forms linked to genetic/neuromuscular disorders    | All ages; congenital in children, acquired in adults; no gender bias |
| **Short stature** (HP:0004322)  | Common phenotype; many nonspecific causes               | Monogenic genetic causes (GH1, GHSR mutations)           | Children of all genders; familial short stature common |
| **Scoliosis** (HP:0002650)      | Common idiopathic scoliosis                              | Congenital/syndromic scoliosis                            | Adolescents (idiopathic), more females; congenital in infants |
| **Vertebral fusion** (HP:0002948) | Rare developmental defect                               | Highly informative for congenital syndromes             | Diagnosed in infants/children; no gender bias    |
| **Camptodactyly of finger** (HP:0100490) | Rare; often congenital or syndromic                    | Informative for syndromic contractures                    | Usually childhood onset; no gender bias           |

---

This analysis integrates clinical and genetic insights from the search results to classify these HPO terms by their diagnostic informativeness and epidemiology.

search_results:
# Analysis of HPO Terms: Clinical Significance and Diagnostic Value

## Short Stature (HP:0004322)

**Common vs. Rare and Informative**

Short stature is a **common and less informative** symptom for specific disease diagnosis. It affects approximately 2.5% of children and is one of the most frequent reasons for consulting a growth specialist[5]. The condition has numerous etiologies, ranging from familial short stature (FSS) to growth hormone deficiency, Turner syndrome, nutritional deficiencies, and various genetic mutations[3][5]. Because of its broad differential diagnosis, short stature alone is insufficient for identifying a specific underlying condition.

**Gender and Age Considerations**

Short stature can affect both males and females equally, though certain conditions associated with short stature show gender predilection. For example, Turner syndrome, which causes short stature, exclusively affects females[7]. Short stature typically becomes clinically apparent during childhood and is most commonly evaluated between ages 4-6 years, when growth patterns become more evident[7].

## Scoliosis (HP:0002650)

**Common vs. Rare and Informative**

Scoliosis is a **moderately common but non-specific** finding. While it can occur as an isolated condition, it also appears as a secondary manifestation in various genetic and systemic disorders. In the context of growth disorders, scoliosis can worsen during accelerated growth periods, particularly in children receiving growth hormone therapy for conditions like Turner syndrome[7].

**Gender and Age Considerations**

Scoliosis shows a female predominance in idiopathic cases, with girls being more frequently affected than boys. It typically develops during childhood and adolescence, with progression most likely during periods of rapid growth. Girls with Turner syndrome receiving growth hormone therapy are at increased risk for scoliosis worsening, presumably due to accelerated growth rates[7].

## Camptodactyly (HP:0012385) and Camptodactyly of Finger (HP:0100490)

**Common vs. Rare and Informative**

Camptodactyly is a **rare and highly informative** condition. It occurs in approximately 1% of the world population[2] and represents a specific structural abnormality of the hand. The condition is characterized by permanent flexion contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint, most commonly affecting the fifth finger (pinky)[10]. While camptodactyly can occur sporadically or as part of various congenital syndromes, its presence is diagnostically significant and warrants investigation for underlying genetic or syndromic causes[2][4].

**Genetic Inheritance and Specificity**

Camptodactyly follows an **autosomal dominant inheritance pattern with incomplete penetrance**[16]. This means that affected individuals may show the condition in both hands, one hand, or neither hand, despite carrying the genetic mutation. The condition is associated with numerous congenital syndromes including Marfan syndrome, Freeman-Sheldon syndrome, Beals syndrome, and others[2].

**Gender and Age Considerations**

Camptodactyly affects both males and females equally and is typically present at birth as a congenital condition. It is very rarely seen in children (1% prevalence), and most cases occur unilaterally (66%) rather than bilaterally (33%)[4]. The condition is most effectively treated surgically while the child is young and bones are not fully matured[6].

## Vertebral Fusion (HP:0002948)

**Common vs. Rare and Informative**

Vertebral fusion is a **rare and moderately informative** finding. While congenital vertebral fusion can occur as an isolated anomaly, it is more commonly associated with specific genetic syndromes and skeletal dysplasias. Its presence suggests an underlying developmental or genetic disorder affecting spinal development.

**Gender and Age Considerations**

Vertebral fusion is a congenital condition present from birth and affects both males and females. It is typically identified through imaging studies during childhood, often when investigating other symptoms or during evaluation for spinal abnormalities.

## Ptosis (HP:0000508)

**Common vs. Rare and Informative**

Ptosis is a **common but non-specific** finding that can result from numerous etiologies including neuromuscular disorders, nerve compression, muscular dystrophies, and various genetic syndromes. While ptosis can be associated with specific conditions, it is not highly informative for disease diagnosis without additional clinical context[1].

**Gender and Age Considerations**

Ptosis can affect both males and females and can present at any age depending on the underlying cause. Congenital ptosis may be present from birth, while acquired ptosis can develop at any point during life. There is no significant gender predilection for ptosis in general, though specific conditions causing ptosis may show gender-specific patterns.

## Summary Table

| HPO Term | Rarity | Diagnostic Specificity | Gender Predilection | Age of Onset |
|----------|--------|------------------------|-------------------|--------------|
| Short stature | Common | Low | Equal | Childhood |
| Scoliosis | Moderate | Low-Moderate | Female predominance | Childhood/Adolescence |
| Camptodactyly | Rare | High | Equal | Congenital |
| Vertebral fusion | Rare | Moderate | Equal | Congenital |
| Ptosis | Common | Low | Equal | Variable |

search_results:
Here is an analysis of the seven provided HPO terms (Scoliosis, Strabismus, Narrow mouth, Camptodactyly, Motor delay, Elbow flexion contracture, Flexion contracture) regarding their commonality, informativeness for specific diseases, and any gender or age predilections:

| HPO Term               | Commonality & Informativeness                                                                                      | Rare & Informative for Specific Diseases                                                                                 | Gender or Age Group Predilection                                                                                          |
|-----------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **HP:0002650 Scoliosis** | Common musculoskeletal abnormality; often seen in many conditions and idiopathic cases; less specific alone.       | When combined with other features, can be informative for syndromes like Marfan, Ehlers-Danlos, or congenital disorders. | More common in adolescents (adolescent idiopathic scoliosis); no strong gender bias but some types more in females.         |
| **HP:0000486 Strabismus** | Relatively common (approx. 4% prevalence in general population); less specific as it occurs in many conditions.    | Informative in syndromes with neurological or developmental involvement (e.g., Down syndrome, cerebral palsy).             | More common in children, often congenital or early onset; can occur at any age; no strong gender bias.                      |
| **HP:0000160 Narrow mouth** | Less common, more specific morphological feature; informative for syndromes with craniofacial dysmorphology.       | Informative in syndromes like Freeman-Sheldon syndrome, orofacial cleft syndromes, and other rare genetic disorders.        | Typically identified in infants or children during clinical genetic evaluation; no strong gender bias.                      |
| **HP:0012385 Camptodactyly** | Relatively rare; more specific; informative for connective tissue or skeletal syndromes.                          | Seen in syndromes like distal arthrogryposis, Freeman-Sheldon syndrome, and other rare genetic disorders.                   | Usually congenital or early childhood onset; no strong gender bias reported.                                                |
| **HP:0001270 Motor delay** | Common developmental feature; less specific alone as it occurs in many neurodevelopmental disorders.               | Informative when combined with other features, can indicate specific neurogenetic syndromes or metabolic disorders.        | More common in infants and young children during developmental assessment; no strong gender bias.                           |
| **HP:0002987 Elbow flexion contracture** | Rare and more specific; informative for musculoskeletal or connective tissue disorders.                         | Seen in arthrogryposis multiplex congenita, certain skeletal dysplasias, and neuromuscular diseases.                      | Usually congenital or early childhood onset; no strong gender bias.                                                        |
| **HP:0001371 Flexion contracture** | Rare and specific; informative for chronic joint abnormalities in genetic or acquired conditions.                 | Seen in connective tissue disorders, arthrogryposis, and some neuromuscular diseases.                                      | Usually congenital or early childhood onset; no strong gender bias.                                                        |

### Detailed Explanation:

1. **Common and Less Informative Terms:**
   - **Scoliosis (HP:0002650)** is a relatively common finding with many causes, including idiopathic forms. Alone, it is less informative for a specific disease but gains specificity when combined with other phenotypes[1].
   - **Strabismus (HP:0000486)** affects about 4% of the population and occurs in many neurological and developmental conditions, making it common but less specific[2][8][10].
   - **Motor delay (HP:0001270)** is a frequent developmental concern in pediatrics and is seen in many neurodevelopmental disorders, thus less specific alone[1].

2. **Rare and Informative Terms:**
   - **Narrow mouth (HP:0000160)** is a specific craniofacial feature that is relatively rare and can be highly informative in diagnosing syndromes with facial dysmorphology[1].
   - **Camptodactyly (HP:0012385)**, a permanent flexion deformity of fingers or toes, is rare and often points to specific genetic syndromes[1].
   - **Elbow flexion contracture (HP:0002987)** and **Flexion contracture (HP:0001371)** are rare joint abnormalities that are informative for musculoskeletal or neuromuscular diseases[1].

3. **Gender or Age Group Predilections:**
   - **Scoliosis** is more common in adolescents, especially adolescent idiopathic scoliosis, with a higher prevalence in females.
   - **Strabismus** typically presents in infancy or early childhood but can occur at any age; no strong gender bias is noted[2][8][10].
   - **Narrow mouth, Camptodactyly, Elbow flexion contracture, and Flexion contracture** are usually congenital or present in early childhood during clinical genetic evaluation, with no clear gender predilection[1].
   - **Motor delay** is assessed in infants and young children during developmental milestones, without a strong gender bias.

### Summary:

- **More common and less specific:** Scoliosis, Strabismus, Motor delay.
- **Rare and more informative:** Narrow mouth, Camptodactyly, Elbow flexion contracture, Flexion contracture.
- **Age groups:** Most terms are identified in infancy or childhood except scoliosis which peaks in adolescence.
- **Gender:** Scoliosis shows female predominance; others have no strong gender bias.

This classification aligns with the HPO structure where terms with higher annotation frequency (common features) have lower information content and are less specific, while rare features have higher information content and are more informative for diagnosis[1].

hpo_input.definition: "Testis in inguinal canal. That is, absence of one or both testes from the scrotum owing to failure of the testis or testes to descend through the inguinal canal to the scrotum." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:23650202]

hpo_input.name: Delayed speech and language development
hpo_input.definition: "A degree of language development that is significantly below the norm for a child of a specified age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Long philtrum
hpo_input.definition: "Distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Scoliosis
hpo_input.definition: "The presence of an abnormal lateral curvature of the spine." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Cobb angle greater than ten degrees

hpo_input.name: Knee flexion contracture
hpo_input.definition: "A type of knee joint contracture in which the knee is in a fixed bent (flexed) configuration such that it cannot be straightened actively or passively." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:31282072]

hpo_input.name: Flexion contracture
hpo_input.definition: "A flexion contracture is a bent (flexed) joint that cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement of joints." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Flexed joint that cannot be straightened
