# Analysis of HPO Terms and Their Clinical Significance

## Slanting of the Palpebral Fissure (HP:0200006)

**Commonality and Informativeness:**
Slanting of the palpebral fissure is a relatively common facial feature that appears across multiple genetic syndromes, making it less specific for diagnosis on its own. Down-slanted palpebral fissures are commonly seen in genetic syndromes such as Noonan syndrome, Treacher Collins syndrome, or Marfan syndrome[2]. This feature can manifest as either downward or upward slanting, and its presence alongside other distinct features aids in clinical diagnosis rather than serving as a definitive marker[2].

**Rarity and Diagnostic Value:**
While the feature itself is not rare, specific patterns of slanting combined with other craniofacial features can be more informative. For example, the combination of downslanted palpebral fissures with other characteristics like hypertelorism, arched eyebrows, and specific ear morphology may point toward particular syndromes[5].

**Gender and Age Considerations:**
The search results do not indicate gender or age-specific prevalence for this feature. Slanting of the palpebral fissure is typically congenital and detectable at birth as part of general craniofacial dysmorphism[5].

---

## Micrognathia (HP:0000347)

**Commonality and Informativeness:**
Micrognathia (underdevelopment of the mandible) is a relatively common craniofacial feature that can appear in various genetic syndromes and conditions. While it is a recognizable feature, it is not highly specific on its own and requires evaluation alongside other clinical findings for accurate diagnosis.

**Rarity and Diagnostic Value:**
Micrognathia becomes more diagnostically valuable when present with other specific features. For instance, it may be part of a recognizable pattern in syndromes affecting craniofacial development, but the search results do not provide specific information about which syndromes feature micrognathia as a particularly distinctive marker.

**Gender and Age Considerations:**
The search results do not provide gender-specific information regarding micrognathia. However, this feature is typically present from birth or becomes apparent during early development.

---

## Abnormal Soft Palate Morphology (HP:0100736)

**Commonality and Informativeness:**
Abnormal soft palate morphology is a relatively nonspecific feature that can occur in various genetic and developmental conditions. The search results mention cleft lip and/or palate as features in conditions like Kabuki syndrome[1], but do not provide detailed information about soft palate morphology specifically as a diagnostic marker.

**Rarity and Diagnostic Value:**
This feature alone is not particularly rare or highly informative for specific disease diagnosis. It typically requires correlation with other systemic features and genetic findings for meaningful clinical interpretation.

**Gender and Age Considerations:**
The search results do not provide gender or age-specific prevalence data for abnormal soft palate morphology.

---

## Hearing Impairment (HP:0000365)

**Commonality and Informativeness:**
Hearing impairment is a relatively common feature across multiple genetic syndromes and is therefore less specific for diagnosis on its own. It appears as a feature in several rare genetic conditions but is not unique to any particular disorder. The search results mention hearing loss as a feature in Kabuki syndrome[1], but this is one of many systemic features.

**Rarity and Diagnostic Value:**
While hearing loss itself is not rare as a symptom, its presence in combination with other specific features can contribute to syndrome identification. However, hearing impairment alone has limited diagnostic specificity.

**Gender and Age Considerations:**
The search results do not indicate gender-specific prevalence for hearing impairment in genetic syndromes. Hearing loss can be congenital or develop over time depending on the underlying condition.

---

## Short Thumb (HP:0009778)

**Commonality and Informativeness:**
Short thumb (thumb hypoplasia) is a relatively specific skeletal feature that can be more informative than some other features. While it appears in various genetic conditions, its presence may narrow the differential diagnosis when combined with other findings.

**Rarity and Diagnostic Value:**
Short thumb can be more diagnostically valuable than nonspecific features like hearing loss or palatal abnormalities. The search results mention persistent fingertip pads and skeletal differences in Kabuki syndrome[1], suggesting that specific hand and thumb morphology can be part of recognizable syndrome patterns.

**Gender and Age Considerations:**
The search results do not provide gender-specific information regarding short thumbs. This feature is typically congenital and apparent from birth or early infancy.

---

## Summary Comparison

| HPO Term | Commonality | Diagnostic Specificity | Gender/Age Notes |
|----------|-------------|------------------------|------------------|
| Slanting of palpebral fissure | Common | Low-moderate | Congenital; no gender specificity noted |
| Micrognathia | Moderate | Low-moderate | Congenital; no gender specificity noted |
| Abnormal soft palate morphology | Moderate | Low | Congenital; no gender specificity noted |
| Hearing impairment | Common | Low | Variable onset; no gender specificity noted |
| Short thumb | Moderate | Moderate-high | Congenital; no gender specificity noted |

The search results do not provide sufficient information to definitively rank all features by rarity or to identify specific gender or age groups more likely to present with these features. Most of these features are congenital and present from birth or early development.

search_results:
Here is a detailed analysis of each HPO term regarding their commonality, informativeness for specific diseases, and any gender or age predilections, based on the search results:

| HPO Term                          | Commonality & Informativeness                                                                                                    | Rare & Informative for Specific Diseases                                                                                              | Gender/Age Predilection                                                                                                  |
|----------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **HP:0200006 Slanting of the palpebral fissure** | This feature is relatively common and less specific, seen in multiple genetic syndromes such as Noonan syndrome, Treacher Collins syndrome, Marfan syndrome, and Saethre-Chotzen syndrome. It is a facial dysmorphism that alone is less informative but can support diagnosis when combined with other features[7][5][15]. | Down-slanted palpebral fissures are particularly noted in Noonan syndrome, Treacher Collins syndrome, Marfan syndrome, and Saethre-Chotzen syndrome, making it informative in these contexts[7][5]. | No specific gender predilection; present from birth or early childhood as a congenital facial feature[7][5].                |
| **HP:0011800 Midface retrusion** | Midface retrusion is a common craniofacial feature in several syndromes including Crouzon syndrome, Muenke syndrome, and other craniosynostoses. It is less specific alone but important in syndromic diagnosis and surgical planning[2][4][6][8]. | Highly informative in syndromes like Crouzon syndrome, Muenke syndrome, Apert syndrome, Pfeiffer syndrome, and achondroplasia. It is a key diagnostic and treatment feature in these disorders[2][4][6][8]. | No specific gender bias; presents congenitally or in early childhood. Familial predisposition is noted in some cases[4].      |
| **HP:0000347 Micrognathia**       | Micrognathia is a common developmental anomaly of the mandible seen in many syndromes and conditions, including Pierre Robin sequence, Treacher Collins syndrome, and others. Alone, it is less specific but important clinically[1][5]. | Informative in syndromes with mandibular hypoplasia such as Treacher Collins syndrome, Pierre Robin sequence, and some craniofacial syndromes[1][5]. | No specific gender predilection; typically congenital and apparent in infancy or early childhood.                          |
| **HP:0100736 Abnormal soft palate morphology** | This is a less common but important feature often associated with cleft palate syndromes and craniofacial anomalies. It is informative when present with other craniofacial abnormalities[1]. | Informative in syndromes with cleft palate or velopharyngeal insufficiency, such as Kabuki syndrome, Pierre Robin sequence, and other craniofacial disorders[1]. | No specific gender predilection; usually congenital and detected in infancy or early childhood.                           |
| **HP:0000365 Hearing impairment** | Hearing impairment is a common symptom across many genetic and non-genetic conditions. It is less specific alone but important clinically[1][6]. | Informative in syndromes with associated auditory defects, e.g., Kabuki syndrome, Muenke syndrome, and other craniofacial syndromes[1][6]. | No specific gender bias; can be congenital or acquired at any age depending on cause.                                     |
| **HP:0001172 Abnormal thumb morphology** | Abnormal thumb morphology is less common and more specific, often seen in syndromes like Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome, Holt-Oram syndrome, and others. It is informative for diagnosis when present[15]. | Informative in syndromes with limb anomalies such as Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome, Holt-Oram syndrome, and others characterized by thumb deformities[15]. | No specific gender predilection; congenital and usually evident in infancy or early childhood.                            |

### Summary by Question:

1. **More common and less informative HPO terms:**
   - *Slanting of the palpebral fissure* (HP:0200006)
   - *Midface retrusion* (HP:0011800)
   - *Micrognathia* (HP:0000347)
   - *Hearing impairment* (HP:0000365)

   These features occur in multiple syndromes and conditions and are often seen in various craniofacial or genetic disorders, making them less specific alone.

2. **Rare and informative HPO terms for specific diseases:**
   - *Abnormal soft palate morphology* (HP:0100736)  informative in cleft palate and related syndromes.
   - *Abnormal thumb morphology* (HP:0001172)  informative in syndromes with limb anomalies.
   - *Midface retrusion* and *micrognathia* can be highly informative in specific craniosynostosis syndromes (e.g., Crouzon, Muenke, Treacher Collins).

3. **Gender or age group predilections:**
   - Most of these features are congenital and present from birth or early childhood.
   - *Hearing impairment* can be congenital or acquired.
   - *Renpenning syndrome* (not directly one of the queried terms but related to intellectual disability and craniofacial features) affects almost exclusively males due to X-linked inheritance, illustrating that some syndromes with these features have gender bias[3].
   - Generally, no strong gender predilection is noted for the listed HPO terms themselves, except when associated with specific X-linked disorders.

This synthesis integrates the clinical relevance, specificity, and demographic tendencies of the listed HPO terms based on current genetic and clinical knowledge from the search results.

search_results:
Here is the synthesized information addressing your three questions for each of the listed HPO terms:

---

### 1. Midface retrusion (HP:0011800)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**
  - Midface retrusion is a relatively common craniofacial feature seen in various syndromes and genetic conditions such as 1p36 deletion syndrome, Kleefstra syndrome, and Williams-Beuren syndrome[1]. It is often less informative by itself because it appears in multiple disorders.
  - It is considered a *skeletal-related symptom* involving underdevelopment or flattening of the midface (infraorbital and perialar regions)[1][3].
- **Rare and Informative Aspects:**
  - When combined with other specific features (e.g., hypertelorism, exophthalmos, parrot-beaked nose), midface retrusion can be more informative for diagnosing rare syndromes like Schinzel-Giedion syndrome[11][13].
- **Gender or Age Predilection:**
  - No specific gender predilection is reported.
  - It is often identified in children and may be congenital or apparent early in life due to developmental anomalies[1][3].

---

### 2. Micrognathia (HP:0000347)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**
  - Micrognathia is a relatively common feature in infants, occurring in about 1 in 1,500 births[6].
  - It is less informative when isolated because it appears in many craniofacial syndromes (e.g., Pierre Robin sequence, Stickler syndrome, Treacher Collins syndrome)[2][6][8].
- **Rare and Informative Aspects:**
  - Micrognathia is highly informative when seen with specific syndromes or associated anomalies (e.g., cleft palate, sleep apnea, feeding difficulties)[2][4][8].
  - Severe micrognathia causing obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and feeding problems is more clinically significant and informative for diagnosis[4][8].
- **Gender or Age Predilection:**
  - No strong gender bias reported.
  - Primarily a congenital condition identified in newborns and infants; symptoms like feeding and breathing difficulties manifest early[2][6][8].

---

### 3. Abnormal soft palate morphology (HP:0100736)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**
  - This term is broad and less specific, describing any abnormality of the soft palate or velum.
  - It is less informative alone because it can be present in many conditions involving cleft palate or muscular abnormalities.
- **Rare and Informative Aspects:**
  - When characterized precisely (e.g., submucous cleft palate, velopharyngeal insufficiency), it can be informative for specific syndromes or congenital anomalies[9].
- **Gender or Age Predilection:**
  - No specific gender or age group is predominantly affected; usually identified in infancy or early childhood during feeding or speech development assessments.

---

### 4. Hearing impairment (HP:0000365)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**
  - Hearing impairment is a common symptom across many genetic and acquired conditions.
  - It is less informative by itself because it is nonspecific and prevalent in various disorders.
- **Rare and Informative Aspects:**
  - Specific types or patterns of hearing loss (e.g., sensorineural vs. conductive) may be more informative diagnostically.
- **Gender or Age Predilection:**
  - Can affect all ages; congenital forms present in infancy or childhood.
  - No clear gender predilection.

---

### 5. Strabismus (HP:0000486)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**
  - Strabismus (eye misalignment) is relatively common in the general population and in many syndromes.
  - It is less informative alone due to its prevalence.
- **Rare and Informative Aspects:**
  - Specific types or early-onset strabismus associated with syndromic features can be informative[9].
- **Gender or Age Predilection:**
  - Often diagnosed in childhood.
  - No strong gender bias.

---

### 6. Mitral valve prolapse (HP:0001634)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**
  - Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is relatively common in the general population (up to 2-3%) and can be benign.
  - It is less informative alone but can be significant when associated with connective tissue disorders (e.g., Marfan syndrome).
- **Rare and Informative Aspects:**
  - MVP with additional cardiac or systemic features can be informative for specific syndromes.
- **Gender or Age Predilection:**
  - MVP is more frequently diagnosed in females.
  - Can present at any age but often detected in adolescence or adulthood.

---

### 7. Abnormal thumb morphology (HP:0001172)

- **Commonality and Informativeness:**
  - Abnormal thumb morphology is less common and more informative because it is often linked to specific syndromes (e.g., Holt-Oram syndrome, Fanconi anemia).
- **Rare and Informative Aspects:**
  - Thumb deformities are considered rare and highly informative for diagnosis of congenital syndromes involving limb anomalies.
- **Gender or Age Predilection:**
  - No specific gender bias.
  - Usually identified at birth or early childhood.

---

**Summary Table:**

| HPO Term                 | Common & Less Informative                  | Rare & Informative                         | Gender/Age Predilection                  |
|--------------------------|-------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------|
| Midface retrusion        | Common in multiple syndromes              | Informative with specific syndromic features | No gender bias; congenital/childhood    |
| Micrognathia             | Common in infants; many syndromes         | Severe cases with OSA, feeding issues     | No gender bias; congenital/infancy      |
| Abnormal soft palate morphology | Broad, less specific                  | Specific palate anomalies in syndromes    | No gender bias; infancy/early childhood |
| Hearing impairment       | Common symptom                            | Specific patterns informative              | All ages; no gender bias                 |
| Strabismus               | Common eye misalignment                   | Early-onset or syndromic forms informative | Childhood; no gender bias                |
| Mitral valve prolapse    | Common, often benign                      | Syndromic associations informative        | More frequent in females; adolescence+  |
| Abnormal thumb morphology| Less common, more specific                | Highly informative for congenital syndromes | No gender bias; birth/early childhood   |

---

This synthesis is based on clinical descriptions, prevalence data, and associations with genetic syndromes from the provided search results[1][2][3][4][6][7][8][9][11][13].

search_results:
# Analysis of HPO Terms and Their Clinical Significance

## Overview of the HPO Terms

Based on the search results, I can provide analysis of these seven HPO terms regarding their specificity, rarity, and demographic associations in genetic syndromes.

## Slanting of the Palpebral Fissure (HP:0200006)

**Common and Less Informative:**
Slanting of the palpebral fissure is a relatively common feature across multiple genetic syndromes. Down-slanted palpebral fissures are commonly seen in genetic syndromes such as Noonan syndrome, Treacher Collins syndrome, and Marfan syndrome[9]. This feature appears frequently enough that it requires additional clinical context and accompanying features to be diagnostically useful.

**Rare and Informative:**
While the general feature is common, specific patterns of slanting combined with other features can be more informative. For example, down-slanting palpebral fissures paired with other distinct craniofacial features aid in clinical diagnosis[9].

**Demographics:**
No specific gender or age predilection is noted in the search results for this feature alone.

## Midface Retrusion (HP:0011800)

**Common and Less Informative:**
Midface retrusion is a relatively common feature across multiple craniofacial syndromes. It affects individuals with Crouzon syndrome, Muenke syndrome, Saethre-Chotzen syndrome, and other conditions[2][4][6][7]. The search results indicate that midface hypoplasia can affect anyone, including those with no medical problems whatsoever, and often has a familial predisposition[4].

**Rare and Informative:**
When midface retrusion appears as part of a specific syndrome constellation with other characteristic features, it becomes more diagnostically valuable. For instance, in Crouzon syndrome, midface retrusion is combined with craniosynostosis and exophthalmos[2].

**Demographics:**
Midface hypoplasia can affect any age group, though it is often present from birth or early childhood in syndromic cases. It can be familial, suggesting inheritance patterns rather than age-specific occurrence[4].

## Micrognathia (HP:0000347)

**Common and Less Informative:**
Micrognathia appears in multiple genetic syndromes and can occur as an isolated feature or as part of broader craniofacial abnormalities. The search results mention underdevelopment of the lower jaw in several syndromes, including Saethre-Chotzen syndrome where most children have underdeveloped lower jaws[7].

**Rare and Informative:**
Micrognathia becomes more informative when it appears alongside specific combinations of other features. For example, in Suleiman-El-Hattab syndrome, micrognathia (small head/microcephaly) appears with a constellation of other distinctive features including synophrys, hypertelorism, and epicanthal folds[1].

**Demographics:**
This feature is typically present from birth (congenital) in syndromic cases and does not show specific gender predilection based on the available information.

## Abnormal Palate Morphology (HP:0000174)

**Common and Less Informative:**
Abnormal palate morphology, including cleft palate, appears across multiple genetic syndromes. The search results mention cleft lip and/or palate in Kabuki syndrome and cleft palate in Saethre-Chotzen syndrome[1][7]. This feature is relatively common across various genetic disorders.

**Rare and Informative:**
Specific palate abnormalities become more informative when combined with other syndrome-specific features. For instance, in Saethre-Chotzen syndrome, cleft palate may appear alongside craniosynostosis and syndactyly[7].

**Demographics:**

Here is a detailed analysis of the six provided HPO terms regarding their commonality, informativeness for specific diseases, and any gender or age predilections, based on the search results and known clinical genetics knowledge:

| HPO Term ID | Name                          | Commonality & Informativeness                                                                                                  | Gender/Age Specificity                                                                                          |
|-------------|-------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| HP:0200006  | Slanting of the palpebral fissure | **Common and less informative:** Slanting of the palpebral fissure (especially down-slanting) is a relatively common dysmorphic feature seen in multiple genetic syndromes such as Noonan syndrome, Treacher Collins syndrome, and Marfan syndrome[9][1][7]. Because it appears in many syndromes, it is less specific and thus less informative by itself for diagnosis. | No strong gender or age specificity; it is a congenital facial feature present from birth and observed across ages[9]. |
| HP:0011800  | Midface retrusion             | **Rare and informative:** Midface retrusion (midface hypoplasia) is a distinctive feature in several syndromic craniosynostoses (e.g., Crouzon syndrome, Muenke syndrome, Apert syndrome) and other craniofacial disorders[2][4][6]. It is informative for diagnosis of these syndromes due to its characteristic facial morphology. | Present from birth; affects both genders equally as these are genetic conditions with autosomal dominant inheritance mostly[2][6]. |
| HP:0000347  | Micrognathia                  | **Rare and informative:** Micrognathia (underdeveloped mandible) is a key diagnostic feature in many syndromes such as Pierre Robin sequence, Treacher Collins syndrome, and others[3]. It is informative because it contributes to characteristic facial phenotypes and functional issues (e.g., feeding, airway). | Congenital feature present from birth, no specific gender predilection known[3].                              |
| HP:0002705  | High, narrow palate           | **Less common but moderately informative:** A high, narrow palate (also called gothic palate) can be seen in various syndromes and some non-syndromic conditions[1]. While it is less common than some other features, it is not highly specific alone but can support diagnosis in combination with other features. | Present from birth; no clear gender or age specificity reported[1].                                            |
| HP:0001172  | Abnormal thumb morphology     | **Rare and informative:** Abnormal thumb morphology (including hypoplasia, duplication, or deformity) is a relatively rare but important diagnostic clue in syndromes such as Holt-Oram syndrome, Fanconi anemia, and others[1]. It is informative because thumb anomalies are less common and often syndrome-specific. | Usually congenital; no strong gender bias but some syndromes with thumb anomalies may have inheritance patterns affecting gender[1]. |
| HP:0004322  | Short stature                | **Common and less informative:** Short stature is a frequent clinical finding in many genetic and non-genetic conditions[1][5]. Because it is common and nonspecific, it is less informative alone but important as part of a broader clinical picture. | Can manifest at any age depending on cause; no gender specificity; often defined as height below 3rd percentile for age/gender[1]. |
| HP:0001159  | Syndactyly                   | **Rare and informative:** Syndactyly (fusion of fingers or toes) is a distinctive and relatively rare feature seen in multiple syndromes such as Saethre-Chotzen syndrome, Apert syndrome, and others[7]. It is informative due to its relative rarity and syndrome associations. | Congenital; no strong gender predilection; usually evident at birth[7].                                        |

### Summary per Question

1. **More common and less informative for specific diseases:**
   - **Slanting of the palpebral fissure (HP:0200006)**
   - **Short stature (HP:0004322)**
   - **High, narrow palate (HP:0002705)** (moderately common, less specific alone)

2. **Rare and informative for specific diseases:**
   - **Midface retrusion (HP:0011800)**
   - **Micrognathia (HP:0000347)**
   - **Abnormal thumb morphology (HP:0001172)**
   - **Syndactyly (HP:0001159)**

3. **Gender or age group specificity:**
   - Most of these features are **congenital** and present from birth.
   - **Short stature** is defined relative to age and gender norms but is not gender-specific.
   - **Renpenning syndrome** (not directly in your list but related to intellectual disability and short stature) is X-linked recessive, affecting mostly males[5].
   - No strong gender predilection is noted for the listed HPO terms themselves, as they mostly reflect structural anomalies present in both sexes.
   - Age specificity is mostly congenital or early childhood, as these are developmental features.

### Additional Notes from Sources:

- **Slanting of palpebral fissure** is a facial feature seen in multiple syndromes and thus less diagnostic on its own[9][1].
- **Midface retrusion** is a hallmark of syndromic craniosynostoses like Crouzon syndrome and Muenke syndrome, often requiring surgical intervention[2][4][6].
- **Micrognathia** is a key feature in syndromes affecting mandibular development, impacting feeding and airway[3].
- **High, narrow palate** is a supportive feature in syndromes but less specific[1].
- **Abnormal thumb morphology** and **syndactyly** are limb anomalies that are more specific and help narrow differential diagnosis[7].
- **Short stature** is a common finding in many genetic disorders but nonspecific alone[1][5].

This synthesis should assist in understanding the diagnostic value and epidemiology of these HPO terms in clinical genetics.

search_results:
# Analysis of HPO Terms: Global Developmental Delay and Scoliosis

## Global Developmental Delay (HP:0001263)

**Commonality and Informativeness**

Global developmental delay is a **more common and less specific term** for identifying particular diseases. Approximately 1-3% of preschool-aged children and roughly 15-17% of children between ages 3 and 17 in the United States experience some form of developmental delay[1][3][9]. This relatively high prevalence makes GDD a broad indicator rather than a disease-specific marker. GDD serves as an umbrella diagnosis that can result from numerous underlying conditions, ranging from genetic disorders to environmental factors, making it less informative for pinpointing a specific disease etiology[1][3].

**Rarity and Disease Specificity**

While GDD itself is common, it is not rare. However, when GDD is associated with specific underlying causessuch as Down syndrome, Fragile X syndrome, or fetal alcohol spectrum disordersthose particular etiologies become more informative for diagnosis[3][4]. hpo_input.name: Global developmental delay
hpo_input.definition: "A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. hpo_input.name: Autism
hpo_input.definition: "Autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impaired social interaction and communication, and by restricted and repetitive behavior. Autism begins in childhood. It is marked by the presence of markedly abnormal or impaired development in social interaction and communication and a markedly restricted repertoire of activity and interest. Manifestations of the disorder vary greatly depending on the developmental level and chronological age of the individual (DSM-IV)." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6410-0882]

hpo_input.name: Delayed speech and language development
hpo_input.definition: "A degree of language development that is significantly below the norm for a child of a specified age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Smooth philtrum
hpo_input.definition: "Flat skin surface, with no ridge formation in the central region of the upper lip between the nasal base and upper vermilion border." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Short philtrum
hpo_input.definition: "Distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border more than 2 SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Short stature
hpo_input.definition: "A height below that which is expected according to age and gender norms. Although there is no universally accepted definition of short stature, many refer to \"short stature\" as height more than 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender (or below the 3rd percentile for age and gender dependent norms)." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

search_results:
Here is a detailed analysis of the six HPO terms based on their commonality, informativeness for specific diseases, and associations with gender or age groups:

| HPO Term | Common vs. Rare & Informativeness | Gender or Age Group Associations |
|----------|----------------------------------|---------------------------------|
| **HP:0001263 Global developmental delay** | **Common but less specific:** Affects about 1-3% of children under 5 years old globally[1][4][5]. It is a broad term describing delays in multiple developmental domains and is often an early indicator of various neurodevelopmental disorders, including intellectual disability and autism. Because it is nonspecific and seen in many conditions, it is less informative for pinpointing a specific disease. | Primarily affects **children younger than 5 years** as per definition[1][4]. Slightly higher incidence in **males** reported, possibly due to X-linked genetic factors[5]. |
| **HP:0000717 Autism** | **Less common but highly informative:** Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) affects about 2.5% of children[5]. It is a specific neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impaired social interaction, communication, and restricted behaviors, making it very informative for diagnosis. | Diagnosed in **early childhood** and persists lifelong[6]. More common in **males** than females, with a male-to-female ratio around 4:1 reported in literature[5][10]. |
| **HP:0000750 Delayed speech and language development** | **Common but less specific:** Speech and language delays occur in 2-19% of children depending on population studied[5]. It is a frequent symptom in many developmental disorders (including autism, intellectual disability, hearing loss), so alone it is less specific for a particular diagnosis. | Most relevant in **young children** during language acquisition phases[1][5]. No strong gender predilection reported, but some studies suggest boys may be more frequently affected. |
| **HP:0000319 Smooth philtrum** | **Rare and informative:** A smooth or flat philtrum is a distinctive facial feature often associated with fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) and some genetic syndromes[3][4]. Because it is a physical sign linked to specific etiologies, it is informative for diagnosis. | No specific gender predilection. Present from **birth** as a congenital facial feature. |
| **HP:0000322 Short philtrum** | **Rare and informative:** Like smooth philtrum, a short philtrum is a distinctive craniofacial feature associated with certain genetic syndromes and fetal alcohol exposure[3]. It is informative for specific diagnoses. | Congenital feature present from **birth**, no specific gender bias reported. |
| **HP:0004322 Short stature** | **Common but nonspecific:** Short stature is defined as height more than 2 SD below the mean for age and gender and can result from numerous causes including genetic syndromes, endocrine disorders, malnutrition, and chronic illness[4][5]. It is common and nonspecific, thus less informative alone. | Can affect **any age group** but typically assessed in **children and adolescents** during growth monitoring[4]. No inherent gender bias, but growth standards are gender-specific. |

### Summary by question:

1. **More common and less informative terms for specific diseases:**
   - Global developmental delay (HP:0001263)
   - Delayed speech and language development (HP:0000750)
   - Short stature (HP:0004322)

   These are frequent findings in pediatric populations and can be caused by a wide range of conditions, making them less specific for diagnosing a particular disease.

2. **Rare and informative terms for specific diseases:**
   - Smooth philtrum (HP:0000319)
   - Short philtrum (HP:0000322)
   - Autism (HP:0000717)

   These terms are more specific. Smooth and short philtrum are distinctive physical signs often linked to fetal alcohol spectrum disorders and some genetic syndromes. Autism is a well-defined neurodevelopmental disorder with characteristic behavioral features.

3. **Gender or age group associations:**
   - **Global developmental delay** and **delayed speech/language** primarily affect children under 5 years old; males may have a slightly higher risk for developmental delays due to genetic factors.
   - **Autism** is diagnosed in early childhood and is more common in males.
   - **Smooth and short philtrum** are congenital features present from birth with no gender bias.
   - **Short stature** is assessed in children and adolescents during growth monitoring, with no gender bias but gender-specific growth norms.

This synthesis integrates epidemiological data, clinical definitions, and typical demographic patterns from multiple authoritative sources[1][3][4][5][6][10].

search_results:
For the HPO term **HP:0000717 "Autism"**, here is the relevant information addressing your three questions:

1. **Common and less informative HPO terms for specific diseases:**
   - Autism (HP:0000717) is a **common neurodevelopmental disorder** with a prevalence of about 1 in 31 children in the U.S. and 1 in 45 adults[1][3]. Because autism occurs across many genetic and environmental conditions, it is relatively **less informative as a specific disease marker** on its own, given its broad phenotypic and etiological heterogeneity[9].
   - Autism is also frequently reported in various syndromes and genetic disorders, such as 16q24.3 microdeletion syndrome, where it is one of several phenotypic features but not unique or rare[7].

2. **Rare and informative HPO terms for specific diseases:**
   - While autism itself is common, its presence in combination with other rare phenotypic abnormalities (e.g., specific craniofacial features, brain malformations) can be **informative for diagnosing rare genetic syndromes**[7].
   - For example, autism combined with features like hypoplasia of the corpus callosum, colpocephaly, or specific dysmorphic features can point to rare microdeletion syndromes or other genetic disorders[7].
   - Autism with early onset (by age 3) and co-occurrence with intellectual disability or other neurological symptoms can be more informative in the context of specific genetic diagnoses[9].

3. **Specific gender or age groups more likely to have these HPO terms:**
   - Autism is diagnosed **more frequently in males than females**, with a male-to-female ratio historically estimated around 4:1 but more recent meta-analyses suggesting closer to 3:1[1][2][6][10].
   - Boys are about 4 times more likely to be diagnosed with autism than girls in the U.S., though this gap may partly reflect diagnostic biases and differences in symptom presentation in females[1][2][4][6].
   - Autism typically **begins in early childhood**, with reliable diagnosis possible by age 2 but average diagnosis age around 4-5 years in the U.S.[1][3].
   - Girls with autism are often diagnosed later than boys and may present with more subtle symptoms, leading to underdiagnosis or misdiagnosis[2][4][12].
   - Autism occurs across all racial and ethnic groups but prevalence rates vary slightly among them[1][3].
   - Additionally, there is emerging evidence of a higher prevalence of gender diversity among autistic individuals compared to the general population, with about 7.4% of autistic people identifying as gender diverse, and a somewhat higher prevalence among those assigned female at birth[8][14].

In summary, **autism is a common and broadly defined HPO term that is less specific for individual diseases but becomes more informative when combined with other rare phenotypic features. It predominantly affects males and is typically diagnosed in early childhood, though diagnostic biases affect gender ratios.**

Here is an analysis of the seven HPO terms you provided, addressing the three questions for each term based on the search results and known clinical/genetic information:

| HPO Term (ID & Name) | 1. Commonality & Informativeness (More common, less informative) | 2. Rarity & Informativeness (Rare, more informative) | 3. Gender or Age Predilection |
|----------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------|
| **HP:0001760 - Abnormal foot morphology** | This is a broad and relatively common finding seen in many conditions, including inherited foot deformities like flat feet, high arches, bunions, and clubfoot. Because it is nonspecific and can be influenced by genetics, environment, and lifestyle, it is less informative for pinpointing a specific disease[1][2][6]. | Certain specific abnormal foot morphologies (e.g., clubfoot, high-arched feet in Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease) are rarer and can be more informative diagnostically, especially when combined with other features[4][6]. | Some foot deformities have gender predilections; for example, clubfoot is about twice as common in boys than girls[6]. Foot morphology also varies with age and weight in children, with overweight children showing different foot structure patterns[5]. |
| **HP:0000508 - Ptosis** | Ptosis (drooping upper eyelid) is a relatively common clinical sign that can be caused by many conditions, including aging, nerve palsies, or myopathies. Alone, it is less specific and less informative for a particular disease[general clinical knowledge]. | Ptosis is more informative when it occurs congenitally or as part of syndromes (e.g., congenital myasthenic syndromes, mitochondrial diseases). In such contexts, it is a rare and valuable diagnostic clue[general clinical knowledge]. | Ptosis can occur at any age but congenital ptosis is present at birth. No strong gender predilection is generally reported. |
| **HP:0000347 - Micrognathia** | Micrognathia (small lower jaw) is a common feature in many genetic syndromes and congenital anomalies, making it relatively common but moderately informative depending on context[3][8]. | It is rare and highly informative when associated with syndromes like Pierre Robin sequence, Treacher Collins syndrome, or overgrowth syndromes with mandibular hypoplasia[3][8]. | Micrognathia is congenital, thus present from birth. It is not strongly gender-specific but is often identified in pediatric populations. |
| **HP:0001371 - Flexion contracture** | Flexion contractures are common in many musculoskeletal and neurological conditions, including arthritis and neuromuscular disorders, thus less specific and less informative alone[general clinical knowledge]. | Rare forms or specific joint contractures (e.g., in genetic syndromes or severe neuromuscular diseases) are more informative diagnostically[general clinical knowledge]. | Can occur at any age depending on the underlying cause; no strong gender predilection. |
| **HP:0012385 - Camptodactyly** | Camptodactyly (permanent flexion of finger or toe joints) is relatively common as an isolated finding or familial trait, so less informative alone[3]. | When part of syndromes (e.g., distal arthrogryposis), it is rare and informative for diagnosis[3]. | Usually congenital or early onset; no strong gender bias reported. |
| **HP:0005830 - Flexion contracture of toe** | Similar to flexion contracture generally, toe contractures are common in foot deformities and neuromuscular conditions, thus less specific[1][2]. | Rare and informative when associated with specific genetic syndromes or neuromuscular diseases like Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease[4][5]. | May appear in childhood or adulthood depending on cause; no clear gender predilection. |
| **HP:0030084 - Clinodactyly** | Clinodactyly (curved digit) is a common minor anomaly seen in the general population and many syndromes, so less informative alone[3]. | It is rare and more informative when part of syndromes such as Down syndrome or other chromosomal abnormalities[3]. | Present from birth; no significant gender difference. |

### Additional Details:

- **Abnormal foot morphology (HP:0001760)** is very broad. Common foot deformities like flat feet and bunions have significant genetic components but are also influenced by environment and lifestyle, making them common but less specific[1][2]. More specific morphologies like clubfoot are rarer and more diagnostic; clubfoot is about twice as common in males and often identified at birth[6].

- **Ptosis (HP:0000508)** is a common clinical sign with many causes. Congenital ptosis or ptosis as part of syndromes is rare and informative. It can present in any age group but congenital forms are evident early.

- **Micrognathia (HP:0000347)** is a developmental hypoplasia of the mandible, common in multiple syndromes and congenital anomalies. It is a key diagnostic feature in several rare syndromes and is present from birth[3][8].

- **Flexion contracture (HP:0001371)** and **flexion contracture of toe (HP:0005830)** are common secondary features in many musculoskeletal and neuromuscular disorders. They are less informative alone but can be diagnostic in rare syndromes or inherited neuropathies like Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, which affects foot muscles and morphology[4][5].

- **Camptodactyly (HP:0012385)** and **clinodactyly (HP:0030084)** are common minor anomalies. They are less informative alone but can be part of syndromic diagnoses when combined with other features[3].

- None of these terms show strong gender predilection except clubfoot (male predominance) and some foot deformities that may be more common in women due to footwear and ligament laxity[2][6].

- Age is relevant: many of these features are congenital or appear in childhood (micrognathia, clubfoot, camptodactyly, clinodactyly), while others (flexion contractures) can develop later depending on underlying disease.

This synthesis integrates genetic, clinical, and epidemiological data to categorize the HPO terms by their commonality, informativeness, and demographic associations.

hpo_input.name: Gastroparesis
hpo_input.definition: "Decreased strength of the muscle layer of stomach, which leads to a decreased ability to empty the contents of the stomach despite the absence of obstruction." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Esophagitis
hpo_input.definition: "Inflammation of the esophagus." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Myoclonus
hpo_input.definition: "Very brief, involuntary random muscular contractions occurring at rest, in response to sensory stimuli, or accompanying voluntary movements." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:20589866]

hpo_input.name: Syncope
hpo_input.definition: "Syncope is a syndrome in which loss of consciousness is of relatively sudden onset, temporary (usually less than 1 to 2 minutes), self-terminating, and of usually rapid recovery. Syncope leads to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:29255499]

hpo_input.name: Seizure
hpo_input.definition: "A seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterized by a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:15816939]

hpo_input.name: Arachnoid cyst
hpo_input.definition: "An extra-parenchymal and intra-arachnoidal collection of fluid with a composition similar to that of cerebrospinal fluid." [https://orcid.org/0009-0006-4530-3154]
synonym: Fluid-filled sac located in membrane surrounding brain or spinal cord

hpo_input.name: Spastic paraplegia
hpo_input.definition: "Spasticity and weakness of the leg and hip muscles." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Autoimmunity
hpo_input.definition: "The occurrence of an immune reaction against the organism's own cells or tissues." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Global developmental delay
hpo_input.definition: "A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6410-0882, https://orcid.org/0009-0006-4530-3154]

hpo_input.name: Spastic diplegia
hpo_input.definition: "Spasticity (neuromuscular hypertonia) primarily in the muscles of the legs, hips, and pelvis." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Spastic paraplegia
hpo_input.definition: "Spasticity and weakness of the leg and hip muscles." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Autoimmunity
hpo_input.definition: "The occurrence of an immune reaction against the organism's own cells or tissues." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Hypotonia
hpo_input.definition: "Hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone (the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle). Even when relaxed, muscles have a continuous and passive partial contraction which provides some resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia thus manifests as diminished resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia is not the same as muscle weakness, although the two conditions can co-exist." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:21418198]

hpo_input.name: Clonus
hpo_input.definition: "A series of rhythmic and involuntary muscle contractions (at a frequency of about 5 to 7 Hz) that occur in response to an abruptly applied and sustained stretch." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]
synonym: Involuntary rhythmic muscular contractions and relaxations

hpo_input.name: Lower limb spasticity
hpo_input.definition: "Spasticity (velocity-dependent increase in tonic stretch reflexes with increased muscle tone and hyperexcitable tendon reflexes) in the muscles of the lower limbs, hips, and pelvis." [HPO_CONTRIBUTOR:UKT_rschuele, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

search_results:
# Analysis of HPO Terms

Based on the search results provided, I can only provide comprehensive information about **Gastroparesis (HP:0002578)** and **Esophagitis (HP:0100633)**, as these are the only conditions covered in the search results. The other HPO terms (Myoclonus, Syncope, Seizure, Arachnoid cyst, Spastic paraplegia, Autoimmunity, Global developmental delay, Spastic diplegia, Hypotonia, Clonus, and Lower limb spasticity) are not addressed in the provided search materials.

## Gastroparesis (HP:0002578)

**1. Common vs. Less Informative**

Gastroparesis is relatively common in certain populations. Approximately one-third of people with diabetes develop gastroparesis, making it a frequent complication in diabetic populations[5]. However, as a diagnostic term, it is moderately informative because it describes a functional outcome (delayed gastric emptying) rather than identifying a specific underlying cause. The condition can result from multiple etiologies including diabetes, infections, medications, surgery, and post-COVID complications[2].

**2. Rare and Informative Aspects**

While gastroparesis itself is not rare in diabetic populations, certain presentations are more specific. Post-COVID gastroparesis represents a newer, more specific manifestation[2]. Additionally, gastroparesis induced by newer weight-loss medications like semaglutide represents an emerging and informative presentation[2].

**3. Gender and Age Considerations**

People assigned female at birth are more likely to develop gastroparesis than people assigned male at birth[8]. The condition can occur across age groups, though it is particularly prevalent in adults with diabetes. Notably, gastroparesis can develop in children and adolescents with poorly controlled diabetes.

## Esophagitis (HP:0100633)

**1. Common vs. Less Informative**

Esophagitis is mentioned in the search results as a potential complication of gastroparesis, specifically through gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)[1]. As a standalone term, it is relatively common but less specific for identifying gastroparesis itself, as esophagitis has multiple independent causes beyond gastroparesis.

**2. Rare and Informative Aspects**

When esophagitis occurs as a secondary complication of gastroparesis, it becomes more informative about disease progression and severity. This association indicates that gastroparesis has progressed to affect the upper digestive tract.

**3. Gender and Age Considerations**

The search results do not provide specific gender or age information regarding esophagitis in the context of gastroparesis complications.

## Summary Table

| HPO Term | Informativeness | Gender Predilection | Age Group |
|----------|-----------------|-------------------|-----------|
| Gastroparesis | Moderate (functional descriptor, multiple causes) | Female > Male | All ages, common in adults with diabetes |
| Esophagitis | Low-Moderate (secondary complication) | Not specified | Not specified |

**Note:** The remaining HPO terms in your list are not covered in the provided search results and would require additional medical literature to analyze properly.

Gastroparesis is relatively common in certain populations. Approximately one-third of people with diabetes develop gastroparesis, making it a frequent complication in diabetic populations[5]. However, as a diagnostic term, it is moderately informative because it describes a functional outcome (delayed gastric emptying) rather than identifying a specific underlying cause. The condition can result from multiple etiologies including diabetes, infections, medications, surgery, and post-COVID complications[2].

**2. Rare and Informative Aspects**

While gastroparesis itself is not rare in diabetic populations, certain presentations are more specific. Post-COVID gastroparesis represents a newer, more specific manifestation[2]. Additionally, gastroparesis induced by newer weight-loss medications like semaglutide represents an emerging and informative presentation[2].

**3. Gender and Age Considerations**

People assigned female at birth are more likely to develop gastroparesis than people assigned male at birth[8]. The condition can occur across age groups, though it is particularly prevalent in adults with diabetes. Notably, gastroparesis can develop in children and adolescents with poorly controlled diabetes.

## Esophagitis (HP:0100633)

**1. Common vs. Less Informative**

Esophagitis is mentioned in the search results as a potential complication of gastroparesis, specifically through gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)[1]. As a standalone term, it is relatively common but less specific for identifying gastroparesis itself, as esophagitis has multiple independent causes beyond gastroparesis.

**2. Rare and Informative Aspects**

When esophagitis occurs as a secondary complication of gastroparesis, it becomes more informative about disease progression and severity. This association indicates that gastroparesis has progressed to affect the upper digestive tract.

**3. Gender and Age Considerations**

The search results do not provide specific gender or age information regarding esophagitis in the context of gastroparesis complications.

## Summary Table

| HPO Term | Informativeness | Gender Predilection | Age Group |
|----------|-----------------|-------------------|-----------|
| Gastroparesis | Moderate (functional descriptor, multiple causes) | Female > Male | All ages, common in adults with diabetes |
| Esophagitis | Low-Moderate (secondary complication) | Not specified | Not specified |

Here is the analysis of the provided Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) terms related to seizures and motor abnormalities, addressing the three questions for each term:

| HPO Term                         | Commonality & Informativeness for Disease                                                                                          | Rarity & Informativeness for Disease                                                                                          | Gender or Age Group Predilection                                                                                           |
|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **HP:0001250 Seizure**           | **Common and less informative:** Seizures are a frequent neurological symptom across many diseases, especially epilepsy and neurodevelopmental disorders. As a broad term, it is less specific for diagnosis. | **Rare and informative:** Specific seizure types or patterns (e.g., neonatal seizures, epileptic spasms) are more informative for particular genetic or developmental disorders. | Seizures can occur at any age but are especially common in infancy and childhood in genetic epilepsies. No strong gender bias reported. [1][3][4][5] |
| **HP:0002069 Bilateral tonic-clonic seizure** | **Common and moderately informative:** This seizure type is common in generalized epilepsies and is a hallmark of many epilepsy syndromes but less specific alone. | **Rare and informative:** When occurring in specific contexts (e.g., infancy with SCN8A mutations), it can be highly informative for diagnosis. | More frequent in infancy in certain genetic epilepsies such as SCN8A-related disorders. No clear gender predilection. [1][5] |
| **HP:0002169 Clonus**            | **Less common and moderately informative:** Clonus is a sign of neurological dysfunction, often seen in upper motor neuron lesions or epilepsy-related motor phenomena. | **Rare and informative:** Presence of clonus can indicate specific neurological disorders involving motor pathways or epilepsy syndromes. | Can occur at any age; no specific gender predilection reported. [1] |
| **HP:0002312 Clumsiness**        | **Common and less informative:** Clumsiness is a nonspecific symptom seen in many neurological and developmental disorders. | **Rare and informative:** When severe or presenting early, it may indicate specific cerebellar or neurodevelopmental disorders. | More often noted in children during motor development; no strong gender bias. [1] |

### Detailed Context

1. **Seizure (HP:0001250)**  
   - Defined as a transient abnormality of nervous system physiology due to excessive or synchronous neuronal activity[1].  
   - It is a very common phenotype in many neurological diseases, including genetic epilepsies and neurodevelopmental disorders[3][4].  
   - Because it is broad, it is less informative alone but essential as a foundational phenotype. Specific seizure types or patterns provide more diagnostic value[3].  
   - Seizures frequently begin in infancy or childhood in genetic epilepsies such as those related to SCN2A or SCN8A variants[4][5].  

2. **Bilateral tonic-clonic seizure (HP:0002069)**  
   - Characterized by a tonic phase (sustained muscle contraction) followed by a clonic phase (rhythmic jerking)[1].  
   - Common in generalized epilepsy syndromes but more informative when linked to specific genetic disorders, e.g., SCN8A-related epilepsy often presents with bilateral tonic-clonic seizures in infancy[5].  
   - No gender specificity is noted, but age of onset (infancy) is a key feature in some disorders.  

3. **Clonus (HP:0002169)**  
   - Rhythmic involuntary muscle contractions in response to stretch, often indicating neurological dysfunction[1].  
   - Less common than seizures but informative for motor pathway involvement or certain epilepsy semiologies.  
   - Occurs across ages without gender bias.  

4. **Clumsiness (HP:0002312)**  
   - Defined as lack of coordination leading to dropping items or bumping into objects[1].  
   - A nonspecific but common symptom in many neurological and developmental conditions.  
   - More informative when severe or associated with other neurological signs. Typically observed in children during motor development stages.  

### Summary

- **More common and less informative terms:** *Seizure* (HP:0001250) and *Clumsiness* (HP:0002312) are broad and frequent symptoms seen in many disorders.  
- **Rare and more informative terms:** *Bilateral tonic-clonic seizure* (HP:0002069) and *Clonus* (HP:0002169) are less common and can be more specific indicators of particular neurological or genetic diseases.  
- **Age and gender:** Seizures and related motor phenomena often present in infancy or childhood in genetic epilepsies, with no strong gender predilection documented. Clumsiness is more noted in children during development.  

This analysis is based on the HPO definitions and recent literature on genetic epilepsies and neurodevelopmental disorders[1][3][4][5].

hpo_input.name: Orofacial cleft
hpo_input.definition: "The presence of a cleft (gap, opening, or groove) in the oral cavity, including cleft of the upper lip and/or cleft of the palate. Cleft of the upper lip is visible as a groove or fissure in the lip, most frequently due to a congenital failure of the maxillary and median nasal processes to fuse. Cleft palate is characterized by a grooved depression or fissure in the roof of the mouth, most often resulting from a congenital failure of the palate to fuse properly. Clefts of the lip and palate can occur individually or together. It is preferable to code each defect separately." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-4142-7153, https://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/birthdefects/surveillancemanual/chapters/chapter-4/chapter4-6.html, PMID:21331089]

search_results:
# Analysis of HPO Terms in Clinical Context

## Overview of the HPO Terms

The seven HPO terms provided represent various phenotypic features that can appear in genetic and congenital conditions. Based on the search results focused on micrognathia, I can provide analysis on how these terms relate to disease specificity and clinical utility.

## Common vs. Rare and Informative Terms

**Common and Less Informative Terms:**

The following HPO terms are relatively common in the general population and therefore less specific for identifying particular diseases:

- **Prominent nose (HP:0000448)**: This is a normal anatomical variation seen frequently in the general population and appears in many different conditions and ethnic backgrounds. It provides minimal diagnostic specificity.

- **Protruding ear (HP:0000411)**: Similarly, ear prominence is a common anatomical variant that occurs in many individuals without any underlying genetic condition.

- **Cupped ear (HP:0000378)**: While more specific than protruding ears, cupped ears still appear in various conditions and can be a normal variant.

- **Supernumerary nipple (HP:0002558)**: This occurs in approximately 0.2-5% of the population and, while unusual, is not highly specific to any particular disease.

**Rare and Highly Informative Terms:**

- **Micrognathia (HP:0000347)**: This is a highly informative term with significant diagnostic value. Micrognathia occurs in approximately 1 in 1,500 to 5,000 live births[1][4] and is strongly associated with specific genetic syndromes including Pierre Robin sequence, Treacher Collins syndrome, Stickler syndrome, and others[2][4][6]. When present, micrognathia often indicates an underlying genetic condition requiring investigation.

- **Orofacial cleft (HP:0000202)**: This is a rare and highly specific finding. Cleft lip and/or palate is the most common birth defect in the United States, affecting approximately 1 in 700 babies[4]. Importantly, orofacial clefts are frequently associated with micrognathia, particularly in Pierre Robin sequence where the small jaw causes tongue displacement leading to cleft palate[1].

- **Eyelid coloboma (HP:0000625)**: This is a rare and specific finding that, when present, strongly suggests particular genetic syndromes and warrants genetic evaluation.

## Age and Gender Considerations

**Age-Related Patterns:**

The search results indicate that most of these HPO terms present at birth or in early infancy:

- **Micrognathia** is typically congenital and present at birth[5][8]. Notably, micrognathia often corrects itself during growth, with jaw growth occurring particularly between 6 and 18 months of age and again during puberty[6][8].

- **Orofacial clefts** are present at birth and can sometimes be detected prenatally via ultrasound[4][8].

- The other features (prominent nose, protruding ears, cupped ears, supernumerary nipple, eyelid coloboma) are generally present from birth but may become more or less apparent as the child grows.

**Gender Considerations:**

The search results do not provide specific information indicating that any of these HPO terms show gender-specific prevalence patterns. Micrognathia and orofacial clefts appear to affect both males and females, though some genetic syndromes associated with these features may have sex-linked inheritance patterns not detailed in the provided search results.

## Clinical Significance Summary

Micrognathia and orofacial cleft are the most diagnostically valuable terms in this set, as they are relatively rare, strongly associated with specific genetic syndromes, and warrant comprehensive genetic and multidisciplinary evaluation[2][8]. The other terms, while potentially present in affected individuals, are common anatomical variations that provide less diagnostic specificity on their own.

Micrognathia occurs in approximately 1 in 1,500 to 5,000 live births[1][4] and is strongly associated with specific genetic syndromes including Pierre Robin sequence, Treacher Collins syndrome, Stickler syndrome, and others[2][4][6]. When present, micrognathia often indicates an underlying genetic condition requiring investigation.

- **Orofacial cleft (HP:0000202)**: This is a rare and highly specific finding. Cleft lip and/or palate is the most common birth defect in the United States, affecting approximately 1 in 700 babies[4]. Importantly, orofacial clefts are frequently associated with micrognathia, particularly in Pierre Robin sequence where the small jaw causes tongue displacement leading to cleft palate[1].

- **Eyelid coloboma (HP:0000625)**: This is a rare and specific finding that, when present, strongly suggests particular genetic syndromes and warrants genetic evaluation.

## Age and Gender Considerations

**Age-Related Patterns:**

The search results indicate that most of these HPO terms present at birth or in early infancy:

- **Micrognathia** is typically congenital and present at birth[5][8]. Notably, micrognathia often corrects itself during growth, with jaw growth occurring particularly between 6 and 18 months of age and again during puberty[6][8].

- **Orofacial clefts** are present at birth and can sometimes be detected prenatally via ultrasound[4][8].

- The other features (prominent nose, protruding ears, cupped ears, supernumerary nipple, eyelid coloboma) are generally present from birth but may become more or less apparent as the child grows.

**Gender Considerations:**

The search results do not provide specific information indicating that any of these HPO terms show gender-specific prevalence patterns. Micrognathia and orofacial clefts appear to affect both males and females, though some genetic syndromes associated with these features may have sex-linked inheritance patterns not detailed in the provided search results.

## Clinical Significance Summary

Micrognathia and orofacial cleft are the most diagnostically valuable terms in this set, as they are relatively rare, strongly associated with specific genetic syndromes, and warrant comprehensive genetic and multidisciplinary evaluation[2][8]. The other terms, while potentially present in affected individuals, are common anatomical variations that provide less diagnostic specificity on their own.

hpo_input.definition: "Distance between subnasale and pronasale more than two standard deviations above the mean, or alternatively, an apparently increased anterior protrusion of the nasal tip." [PMID:19152422]

hpo_input.name: Micrognathia
hpo_input.definition: "Developmental hypoplasia of the mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Orofacial cleft
hpo_input.definition: "The presence of a cleft (gap, opening, or groove) in the oral cavity, including cleft of the upper lip and/or cleft of the palate. Cleft of the upper lip is visible as a groove or fissure in the lip, most frequently due to a congenital failure of the maxillary and median nasal processes to fuse. Cleft palate is characterized by a grooved depression or fissure in the roof of the mouth, most often resulting from a congenital failure of the palate to fuse properly. Clefts of the lip and palate can occur individually or together. It is preferable to code each defect separately." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-4142-7153, https://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/birthdefects/surveillancemanual/chapters/chapter-4/chapter4-6.html, PMID:21331089]

hpo_input.name: Eyelid coloboma

---

### 1. **HP:0000448  Prominent nose**

**1. Common and less informative?**  
- **No.** A prominent nose is not a common, non-specific feature. It is a distinctive facial trait that is often associated with specific syndromes (e.g., Hallermann-Streiff syndrome, Majewski osteodysplastic primordial dwarfism, and some progeroid syndromes).  
- **Conclusion:** Less common, more informative.

**2. Rare and informative?**  
- **Yes.** Prominent nose is a rare and highly informative feature for certain genetic syndromes, especially those with a progeroid or dysmorphic phenotype.  
- **Example:** Hallermann-Streiff syndrome, Majewski osteodysplastic primordial dwarfism, and the syndrome described in Bacha and Hoo (2001) all feature a prominent nose as a key diagnostic clue.

**3. Gender or age group more likely?**  
- **No strong gender bias.**  
- **Age:** Most commonly noted in infancy or childhood, as it is a congenital or developmental feature.

---

### 2. **HP:0000347  Micrognathia**

**1. Common and less informative?**  
- **Yes.** Micrognathia is a relatively common finding in newborns and is seen in a wide range of syndromes (Pierre Robin sequence, Treacher Collins, Stickler, Noonan, etc.) and even in isolated cases.  
- **Conclusion:** Common, less informative for a specific disease.

**2. Rare and informative?**  
- **No.** Because it is so common and non-specific, micrognathia is not considered rare or highly informative for a single disease. However, when combined with other features (e.g., cleft palate, prominent nose), it can help narrow the differential diagnosis.

**3. Gender or age group more likely?**  
- **No strong gender bias.**  
- **Age:** Most commonly seen in infants and young children, as it is a congenital or developmental feature.

---

### 3. **HP:0000202  Orofacial cleft**

**1. Common and less informative?**  
- **Yes.** Orofacial clefts (cleft lip/palate) are relatively common birth defects and are associated with many syndromes (Pierre Robin, Stickler, Treacher Collins, 22q11.2 deletion, etc.) as well as non-syndromic cases.  
- **Conclusion:** Common, less informative for a specific disease.

**2. Rare and informative?**  
- **No.** Orofacial clefts are not rare and are not specific to any single syndrome. However, the type and combination with other features can be informative.

**3. Gender or age group more likely?**  
- **Gender:** Cleft lip with or without cleft palate is more common in males; isolated cleft palate is more common in females.  
- **Age:** Congenital, present at birth.

---

### 4. **HP:0000625  Eyelid coloboma**

**1. Common and less informative?**  
- **No.** Eyelid coloboma is a rare feature and is not commonly seen in the general population or in most syndromes.  
- **Conclusion:** Rare, more informative.

**2. Rare and informative?**  
- **Yes.** Eyelid coloboma is a rare and highly informative feature, often associated with specific syndromes such as Treacher Collins syndrome, CHARGE syndrome, and other craniofacial disorders.  
- **Example:** Treacher Collins syndrome often features lower eyelid coloboma.

**3. Gender or age group more likely?**  
- **No strong gender bias.**  
- **Age:** Congenital, present at birth.

---

### 5. **HP:0002558  Supernumerary nipple**

**1. Common and less informative?**  
- **Yes.** Supernumerary nipples are relatively common (up to 15% of the population) and are usually benign and non-syndromic.  
- **Conclusion:** Common, less informative for a specific disease.

**2. Rare and informative?**  
- **No.** Supernumerary nipples are not rare and are not specific to any single syndrome. However, in rare cases, they can be associated with certain syndromes (e.g., Poland syndrome, Turner syndrome, or renal anomalies), but this is not the rule.

**3. Gender or age group more likely?**  
- **Gender:** More commonly reported in males.  
- **Age:** Can be present at birth or discovered later in life.

---

### 6. **HP:0000378  Cupped ear**

**1. Common and less informative?**  
- **No.** Cupped ear is a relatively rare and distinctive feature.  
- **Conclusion:** Rare, more informative.

- **Yes.** Cupped ear is a rare and highly informative feature, often seen in syndromes such as Treacher Collins syndrome, CHARGE syndrome, and other craniofacial disorders.  
- **Example:** Treacher Collins syndrome often features cupped or malformed ears.

**3. Gender or age group more likely?**

# Analysis of HPO Terms Related to Micrognathia

## Overview of HPO Terms

Based on the search results provided, I can analyze the clinical significance and diagnostic value of the HPO terms listed in relation to micrognathia and associated conditions.

## HP:0000347 - Micrognathia

**Commonality and Informativeness:**

Micrognathia is a relatively common condition that occurs in approximately 1 in 1,500 to 1 in 5,000 live births[1][4]. While common in infants, it is highly informative for diagnosis because it is the primary defining feature of multiple genetic syndromes. The condition is particularly significant as a diagnostic marker when it appears as part of recognized genetic conditions[2].

**Rarity and Specificity:**

Micrognathia is moderately common but becomes highly specific when associated with particular syndromes such as Pierre Robin sequence, Treacher Collins syndrome, Stickler syndrome, and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome[2][4]. In these contexts, it serves as a key diagnostic indicator.

**Age and Gender Considerations:**

Micrognathia is typically congenital, present at birth[5]. It is relatively common in newborns, with a slightly recessed jaw being a normal part of infant development[5]. The condition often corrects itself between 6 and 18 months of age as children grow[8]. No gender predilection is mentioned in the search results.

## HP:0000347 - Micrognathia

**Commonality and Informativeness:**

Micrognathia is a relatively common condition that occurs in approximately 1 in 1,500 to 1 in 5,000 live births[1][4]. While common in infants, it is highly informative for diagnosis because it is the primary defining feature of multiple genetic syndromes. The condition is particularly significant as a diagnostic marker when it appears as part of recognized genetic conditions[2].

**Rarity and Specificity:**

Micrognathia is moderately common but becomes highly specific when associated with particular syndromes such as Pierre Robin sequence, Treacher Collins syndrome, Stickler syndrome, and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome[2][4]. In these contexts, it serves as a key diagnostic indicator.

**Age and Gender Considerations:**

Micrognathia is typically congenital, present at birth[5]. It is relatively common in newborns, with a slightly recessed jaw being a normal part of infant development[5]. The condition often corrects itself between 6 and 18 months of age as children grow[8]. No gender predilection is mentioned in the search results.

hpo_input.definition: "Developmental hypoplasia of the mandible." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Protruding ear
hpo_input.definition: "Angle formed by the plane of the ear and the mastoid bone greater than the 97th centile for age (objective); or, outer edge of the helix more than 2 cm from the mastoid at the point of maximum distance (objective)." [PMID:19152421]

hpo_input.name: Cupped ear
hpo_input.definition: "Laterally protruding ear that lacks antihelical folding (including absence of inferior and superior crura)." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, PMID:19162421, PMID:22073081]

hpo_input.name: Supernumerary nipple
hpo_input.definition: "Presence of more than two nipples." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199]

hpo_input.name: Eyelid coloboma
hpo_input.definition: "A short discontinuity of the margin of the lower or upper eyelid." [PMID:19125427]
synonym: Full thickness defect of the eyelid

hpo_input.name: Orofacial cleft
hpo_input.definition: "The presence of a cleft (gap, opening, or groove) in the oral cavity, including cleft of the upper lip and/or cleft of the palate. Cleft of the upper lip is visible as a groove or fissure in the lip, most frequently due to a congenital failure of the maxillary and median nasal processes to fuse. Cleft palate is characterized by a grooved depression or fissure in the roof of the mouth, most often resulting from a congenital failure of the palate to fuse properly. Clefts of the lip and palate can occur individually or together. It is preferable to code each defect separately." [https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0736-9199, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-4142-7153, https://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/birthdefects/surveillancemanual/chapters/chapter-4/chapter4-6.html, PMID:21331089]

hpo_input.name: Prominent nose
hpo_input.definition: "Distance between subnasale and pronasale more than two standard deviations above the mean, or alternatively, an apparently increased anterior protrusion of the nasal tip." [PMID:19152422]
